item.title: About
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded: Branko Ajzele is a professional, certified and experienced software developer, focused on eCommerce related applications. Inventive in problem solving on a day-to-day basis, mostly thanks to his rich, hands-on experience with Magento, he feels comfortable proposing alternatives to demands he feels can be improved, even when this means pulling a late shift to meet deadlines. He is no stranger when it comes to topics such as payment and shipping gateways, order and invoice functionalities, various third-party ERP, and fulfillment system integrations with Magento. He holds several respected IT certifications such as Zend Certified Engineer, Magento Certified Developer Plus, and JavaScript Certified Developer. Instant E-Commerce with Magento: Build a Shop by Packt Publishing was his first Magento-related book oriented toward Magento newcomers, after which he decided to write Getting Started with Magento Extension Development for developers. Connect via LinkedIn http://linkd.in/XgLuUz

item.title: Setting up Magento development environment
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Prior to installing fresh new copy of Magento (v1.8.0.0 latest as the time of this writing), you should make sure that your environment meets minimum system requirements like outlined on official Magento site here. Installing Magento can be simple as:
  • creating an empty database table on your local machine
  • downloading the latest Magento (CE) installlation archive from official Magento site
  • unpacking the installation archive to locally configured vhost
  • pointing your browser to your vhost
If you are having trouble installing your Magento, be sure to go through the official installation instructions posted here. This article presumes that you have a fresh new Magento installation that you have just installed on your local machine, either with sample data or without it. If you have a case where you are doing development on a Magento site that is already live, and you need to pull it down and set development environment based on it, then you might find this article interesting as well. Once you have installed your Magento on local machine, there are few more things that need to be addressed before you dive into development. Primarily we are talking about Magento configuration options that need to be turned on or off. Following is a sort of check-list of things that MUST be configured, or else you might experience issues during development. Issues such as not seeing your changes, etc.
  • System > Cache Management > Disable All
  • System > Configuration > Advanced > Developer > Log Settings > Enabled [ Yes ]
  • System > Configuration > Advanced > Developer > Debug > Profiler [ Yes ]. Now, this is optional suggestion, since turning on the Profiler requires you to edit the root index.php file by replacing the #Varien_Profiler::enable(); line with Varien_Profiler::enable(); (uncommenting it) which is ugly. Editing index.php is ugly and should be avoided if possible. This is why I mentioned this as optional step. Turning on the Profiler results in a frontend like the one shown below on screenshots for the default Magento theme.
  • System > Configuration > Web > Search Engine Optimization > Use Web Server Rewrites [ Yes ]
  • System > Configuration > Catalog > Catalog > Frontend > Use Flat Catalog Category [ Yes ]
  • System > Configuration > Catalog > Catalog > Frontend > Use Flat Catalog Product [ Yes ]
  • System > Index Management > Reindex All
  • Open .htaccess and set SetEnv MAGE_IS_DEVELOPER_MODE "true" at the end of the file
  • Open .htaccess and set php_value display_errors On somewhere within <IfModule mod_php5.c>
  • Rename errors / local.xml.sample to errors / local.xml
  • Create one sample customer with full valid US address (this is to test payment and shipping gateways properly). You can help yourself here by using services like http://www.fakenamegenerator.com
  • If you lack the email server, try to possibly compensate for it by directing all Magento emails to log, which is easy (just create a copy of app / code / core / Mage / Core / Model / Email / Template.php under app / code / local / Mage / Core / Model / Email / Template.php and edit the function send (found around line 395), locate the $mail->send(); function call, comment it out, and replace it with something like Mage::log($text, null, 'email_'.time()); or whatever suites your needs, the idea is to log the mail)
  • Setup a version control for your code, preferably GIT. In case of GIT, you might need a .gitignore file oriented towards Magento as the one shown here. Additionally, spare some time to learn a solid git branching model strategy (nvie, igor) as it will help you get self organised and ready for team work.
  • Setup a cron (or schtasks if on Windows) to periodically, every 1 minute, run Magento root folder cron.php. Some of the built in features of Magento depend on scheduled tasks, like Newsletter Subscription, so having cron setup is desirable. To see if your setup is working  fine, truncate the cron_schedule table, it should start filling with some entries when your cron triggers Magento cron.php.
Surely there are many more tweaks and configurations to be done in order to fully prepare your Magento development environment. The above is merely a list of some of the more usual stuff that you should address before diving into the code.
item.excerpt:encoded: This article presumes that you have a fresh new Magento installation that you have just installed on your local machine, either with sample data or without it. If you have a case where you are doing development on a Magento site that is already live, and you need to pull it down and set development environment based on it, then you might find this article interesting as well.

item.title: Magento Cache Management - Programmatically Refresh Invalidated Cache Type
item.dc:creator: branko
item.excerpt:encoded: Depending on your Magento Indexer Mode settings (Manual Update / Update on Save) you might have the "One or more of the Cache Types are invalidated: Blocks HTML output. Click here to go to Cache Management and refresh cache types." notification message popping out all the time in Magento admin. This message is basically telling you that you need to go under "System > Cache Management" and refresh the invalidated cache types manually. Until you do so, Magento considers the invalidated cache types as disabled. If you have a high traffic store where every second of page generation / page load time counts, then this is an issue. You need to refresh the invalidated cache types as soon as possible. Doing so manually is simply not an viable option, since it takes time and constant monitoring.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Learn how to programmatically refresh invalidated cache type in Magento.
Magento - Programmatically Refresh Invalidated Cache Type

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hi Branko, just a little correction. Mage_Core_Model_Cache::cleanType() receives type code as first parameter and it's doctype is string $typeCode. Your code passes Varien_Object created by foreach what causes:
Recoverable Error: Object of class Varien_Object could not be converted to string
So instead of:
Mage::app()->getCacheInstance()->cleanType($type);
this line should be:
Mage::app()->getCacheInstance()->cleanType($type->getId());
After this correction all works as expected.
Thanks for the snippet, really useful.

item.title: Git ignore (.gitignore) for Magento projects
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Working with GIT version control system is a real pleasure. Ever since I started using it with Magento, branching became a part of my standard workflow. Given the dynamic nature of Magento, its configuration and cache files, it is important to set the .gitignore file before you add anything you your GIT repository. Below is a file I use across Magento projects I am working on. As you can see, it goes down to adding entire Magento installation to repository, minus some of the dynamically generated stuff like var/ folder content, cached media images, etc. Feel free to tune it to your needs. 

# General web stuff
/.htaccess
/robots.txt
/sitemap.xml

# Dynamic Magento data that doesn't need to be in the repo
/var/*
/media/*
/downloader/pearlib/cache/*
/downloader/pearlib/download/*
/app/etc/use_cache.ser
/app/etc/local.xml
/errors/local.xml

# Various IDE & OS files that should never be committed
.DS_Store
*.swp
*.lock
__MACOSX
.idea
/nbproject/*
.project
.buildpath
.thumbs
Thumbs.db
build.properties
.project
.settings
.buildpath
/_notes/*

# Explicitly mark as "do not exclude/ignore these from GIT repository"
!/app/.htaccess
!/downloader/.htaccess
!/downloader/template/.htaccess
!/errors/.htaccess
!/includes/.htaccess
!/lib/.htaccess
!/media/.htaccess
!/media/customer/.htaccess
!/media/downloadable/.htaccess
!/pkginfo/.htaccess
!/var/.htaccess
!var/package/
Notice the last section of my .gitignore file, with all those !. It is important not to exclude, for example, entire var/ directory as you need to preserve the .htaccess, and possibly few other files there. Thus, be sure to check this .gitignore, line by line and possibly modify it to suite your project needs. Hope this helps.
item.excerpt:encoded: Working with GIT version control system is a real pleasure. Ever since I started using it with Magento, branching became a part of my standard workflow. Given the dynamic nature of Magento, its configuration and cache files, it is important to set the .gitignore file before you add anything you your GIT repository.

item.title: Extending Magento SOAP API with your own methods (v1, v2, v2 + WS-I Compliance)
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded: Magento comes with a built in core API that allows third-party applications to interact with it programmatically. The good thing about it, is that it is language-independent so it does not matter what programming language a developer uses, he/she can connect to Magento through the API. Over time, Magento added a lot of methods calls to its API enabling developer do to all sort of actions around: Catalog, Catalog Inventory, Checkout, Create Your Own API, Customer, Directory, Sales entities. This article will show you how to create your own API method that conforms to all three flavors of SOAP API (v1, v2, v2 + WS-I Compliance).<!--more-->

Extending Magento SOAP API with your own methods

item.title: Understanding Magento Quick Search (when less is more)
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Magento comes with a two built in search "tools". One called Quick Search, the other one called Advanced Search. The "Quick Search" tool relies on product attribute "Use in Quick Search [Yes|No]" option, while the "Advanced Search" depends on product attribute "Use in Advanced Search [Yes|No]" option. This article shares some insights into the "Quick Search" as it seems to be more frequently used across stores than "Advanced Search" (not really a rule, it depends how you made your theme, etc.). Quick Search starts from the quick search input field (usually in header, as in default theme), and once submitted it sends its results to a url like: http://magentoce1702.loc/catalogsearch/result/?q=metal+case Advanced Search starts from the advanced search page (usually a page at url like http://magentoce1702.loc/catalogsearch/advanced/, as in default theme), and once submitted it sends its results to a url like: http://magentoce1702.loc/catalogsearch/advanced/result/?name=metal+case&sku=&price%5Bfrom%5D=&price%5Bto%5D= What trips people off when it comes to Quick Search is the amount of results it returns, which is usually more than expected. There are two reasons behind this:
  • when doing a search, user tends to think he is searching just by product name
  • Magento uses OR in place of AND statement in case of multiple word search
There is nothing wrong in both of these reasons, one just needs to understand it in order to use maximum out of it. From now on, everything said goes with premise you are using System > Configuration > Catalog > Catalog > Frontend > Use Flat Catalog Product > [Yes] (as this is the case I was testing against). When user does a search, Magento will look into its attribute definitions, including only the "Use in Quick Search [Yes]" for search results. By default installation, there are several attributes that are set to Yes here (name, sku, description, short_description, ...). At first this does not seem like a big deal, but if you have a large set of products which differentiate clearly by name, but their description has a lot of touching points (same keywords, like "metal case", "unibody", "plastic") then you might get a lot of "non-related" search results. So if you have a large number of custom attributes you assigned to products, what you might want to do is to determine the absolute minimum of the you with to use in Quick Search and set others to "Use in Quick Search [No]". This alone will return smaller search result set for certain keywords that overlap (show up) in other attributes. Also, when doing a multiple keyword search like "metal case" Magento will internally send an OR statement to MySQL, while you might get more targeted result set by using the AND. If you are interested in tuning the Quick Search, here are the few steps to get you started:
  • Do a full DB backup (just in case)
  • Replace "OR" with "AND" app/code/core/Mage/CatalogSearch/Model/Resource/Fulltext.php at line 331 and 355.
    • model rewrite through our custom module (more preferable)
    • placing the app/code/core/Mage/CatalogSearch/Model/Resource/Fulltext.php into app/code/local/Mage/CatalogSearch/Model/Resource/Fulltext.php (faster approach, less preferable)
  • Go into database then run: 
    UPDATE catalog_eav_attribute SET is_searchable = 0;
    This will set all product attributes to "Use in Quick Search" => NO.
  • Go into database then run: 
    UPDATE catalog_eav_attribute SET is_searchable = 1 WHERE attribute_id = (SELECT attribute_id FROM eav_attribute WHERE attribute_code = "name" AND entity_type_id = (SELECT entity_type_id FROM eav_entity_type WHERE entity_type_code = "catalog_product"));
    This will set only the "name" attribute to "Use in Quick Search" => YES, which is sort of the whole point of this article, having one or minimal set of searchable attributes to get more precise result set.
  • Go into database then run: 
    DELETE FROM catalogsearch_query; DELETE FROM catalogsearch_fulltext;
    This will clear all previously built search query.
  • Go into Magento admin, then do a full reindex (actually only Catalog Search Index is relevant for this).
You can easily make an extension for switching Magento between its OR and your AND statement, have it exposed as configuration value under System > Configuration > Catalog > Catalog > Catalog Search > OR/AND. Hope this helps.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Get an insight into the inner workings of Magento Quick Search. Learn how to set it up for your needs by removing non-required attributes from search results.
Understanding Magento Quick Search (when less is more)

item.title: Setting all Magento associated products from a configurable to Not Visible Individually
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
If for some reason you with to change the visibility of all simple products assigned as associated to a configurable products here is a snippet of code that might help. SELECT statement for simply checking them out: 

SELECT * FROM catalog_product_entity_int 
WHERE attribute_id = (SELECT attribute_id FROM eav_attribute WHERE attribute_code = "visibility") 
AND entity_id IN (SELECT product_id FROM catalog_product_super_link WHERE parent_id IN (SELECT entity_id FROM catalog_product_entity WHERE type_id ="configurable"))
AND entity_type_id = (SELECT entity_type_id FROM eav_entity_type WHERE entity_type_code = "catalog_product")
AND value != 1;
UPDATE statement for actually updating (changing visibility to Mage_Catalog_Model_Product_Visibility::VISIBILITY_NOT_VISIBLE [1]): 

UPDATE catalog_product_entity_int SET `value` = 1
WHERE attribute_id = (SELECT attribute_id FROM eav_attribute WHERE attribute_code = "visibility") 
AND entity_id IN (SELECT product_id FROM catalog_product_super_link WHERE parent_id IN (SELECT entity_id FROM catalog_product_entity WHERE type_id ="configurable"))
AND entity_type_id = (SELECT entity_type_id FROM eav_entity_type WHERE entity_type_code = "catalog_product")
AND value != 1;
Hope it helps.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: magento, mass, batch, simple, configurable, associated, visibility
Learn how to mass/batch change the visibility of all simple products used as associated of some configurable product in Magento.
Mass/batch changing Magento associated products visibility

item.title: Magento flash/notification messages + free Magento extension (Foggyline_Messages)
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Default Magento installation has a bunch of system / flash / notification messages that get outputted to the browser. You can think of this as a notification system functionality of Magento (thats the terminology I like to use). It is something every theme and/or extension developer should know about. This notification system uses exactly four different messages or message types. These are: error, warning, notice, success. They are outputted to the browser in the exact same order I just listed them, from top to bottom. What differentiates them on the store frontend is the CSS styling that gets applied to the HTML element containing each message(s). Messages are stored on a session model. Default Magento installation comes with the following session models:
  • 'core/session'
  • 'adminhtml/session'
  • 'customer/session'
  • 'catalog/session'
  • 'catalogsearch/session'
  • 'checkout/session'
  • 'connect/session'
  • 'install/session'
  • 'tag/session'
  • 'wishlist/session'
Each of these session models is capable of accepting those four types of messages by simple ->add{MessageType} method call like shown on the example below. 
Mage::getSingleton('core/session')->addError('Message here');
Mage::getSingleton('core/session')->addWarning('Message here');
Mage::getSingleton('core/session')->addNotice('Message here');
Mage::getSingleton('core/session')->addSuccess('Message here');
Once you add a message to the session model, it will get rendered on the frontend on the next page that gets loaded. Below are several screenshots for some of the Magento section pages so you can visually see how default theme renders messages. Please note that the screens below are result of using 'core/session' model. Using other session models might possibly result in messages getting outputted on different location within page layout, depending on how theme was developed. [caption id="attachment_221" align="alignnone" width="604"] Magento Messages - Home Page[/caption] [caption id="attachment_218" align="alignnone" width="604"] Magento Messages - My Account Page[/caption] [caption id="attachment_222" align="alignnone" width="604"] Magento Messages - Category Page[/caption] [caption id="attachment_220" align="alignnone" width="604"] Magento Messages - Product View Page[/caption] [caption id="attachment_217" align="alignnone" width="604"] Magento Messages - Cart Page[/caption] [caption id="attachment_219" align="alignnone" width="604"] Magento Messages - Checkout Page[/caption] Notice how warning messages are not styled at all, so you might want to give it a slight touch of styling if you are doing a custom theme development, just in case someone decides to throw something in them. Below is an example of HTML that gets outputted in browser for the messages. 
    
    
  • 
        
      
            
    • Error Message Here
      • 
            
    • Error Message & Here
      • 
            
    • Error Message && Here
      • 
            
    • Error Message &&& Here
      • 
        
    
    
    • 
    
  • 
        
      
            
    • Warning Message Here
      • 
            
    • Warning Message & Here
      • 
            
    • Warning Message && Here
      • 
            
    • Warning Message &&& Here
      • 
        
    
    
    • 
    
  • 
        
      
            
    • Notice Message Here
      • 
            
    • Notice Message & Here
      • 
            
    • Notice Message && Here
      • 
            
    • Notice Message &&& Here
      • 
        
    
    
    • 
    
  • 
        
      
            
    • Success Message Here
      • 
            
    • Success Message & Here
      • 
            
    • Success Message && Here
      • 
            
    • Success Message &&& Here
      • 
        
    
    
    •
And the default Magento Community Edition theme CSS styling behind it, as shown below. 
/* Global Messages  */
.success { color:#3d6611; font-weight:bold; }
.error { color:#df280a; font-weight:bold; }
.notice { color:#e26703; }

.messages,
.messages ul { list-style:none !important; margin:0 !important; padding:0 !important; }
.messages { width:100%; overflow:hidden; }
.messages li { margin:0 0 10px !important; }
.messages li li { margin:0 0 3px !important; }
.error-msg,
.success-msg,
.note-msg,
.notice-msg { border-style:solid !important; border-width:1px !important; background-position:10px 9px !important; background-repeat:no-repeat !important; min-height:24px !important; padding:8px 8px 8px 32px !important; font-size:11px !important; font-weight:bold !important; }
.error-msg { border-color:#f16048; background-color:#faebe7; background-image:url(../images/i_msg-error.gif); color:#df280a; }
.success-msg { border-color:#446423; background-color:#eff5ea; background-image:url(../images/i_msg-success.gif); color:#3d6611; }
.note-msg,
.notice-msg { border-color:#fcd344; background-color:#fafaec; background-image:url(../images/i_msg-note.gif); color:#3d6611; }
Once the messages are rendered, they are cleared from session model. This is important to keep in mind, as it tells you basically that it makes no sense to do a message adding within theme (*.phtml) files. Proper way is to add messages through your controller actions, or even block and model classes. You can do a quick search for string /session')->add across entire Magento, this will give you a list of all flash/notification messages Magento uses. The order at which these messages appear on the store frontend and entire HTML output are defined in Mage_Core_Block_Messages class within getGroupedHtml() method, so there is no theme *.phtml file you can edit to change the sort order. In case you ever need to change this order, following is a link to a free Magento extension I wrote. Get Foggyline_Messages (free Magento extension) from GitHub. This extension enables you to change sort order through config, which is available under System > Configuration > General > Design > Foggyline | Messages. Please keep in mind that cases where your store fires all four messages at once are extremely rare, if any, so you might not even notice the results of this config. In case of a faulty config, extension will show default messages order. This should give you enough insight in order to stay on op with Magento flash/notification messages. Hope you find this useful.
item.excerpt:encoded: Default Magento installation has a bunch of system / flash / notification messages that get outputted to the browser. You can think of this as a notification system functionality of Magento (thats the terminology I like to use). It is something every theme and/or extension developer should know about. This notification system uses exactly four different messages or message types. These are: error, warning, notice, success. They are outputted to the browser in the exact same order I just listed them, from top to bottom. What differentiates them on the store frontend is the CSS styling that gets applied to the HTML element containing each message(s).

item.title: Magento Catalog Advanced Search Form - Change the order of the fields
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
No matter how big and modular you are, there is always that little extra something you are missing. Default Magento installation comes with a decent Catalog Advanced Search functionality. Form that gets rendered to browser is a result of Frontend Properties > Use in Advanced Search option set on each attribute entity in Magento, which you can see when editing individual attribute. Controlling this option give you ability to control which form fields are accessible to customer browsing your store. Following is a screenshot of Magento Catalog Advanced Search Form as rendered in the default theme. [caption id="attachment_229" align="alignnone" width="960"] Magento Catalog Advanced Search Form[/caption] HTML behind that gets rendered to the browser for the Actual form elements is as follows. 
    
    
  • 
        
        
    
            
        
    
    
    • 
    
  • 
        

        
    
            
        
    
    
    • 
    
  • 
        
        
    
            
            -
            
            (USD)
        
    
    
    •
Now, unless someone broke this HTML structure within its own custom Magento theme, you can easily manipulate it with just a few lines of JavaScript code. For example, following JavaScript code when placed in header of your page will sort price attribute at the very top and sku attribute right below it, while the rest of the searchable attributes remain their order.
Easy, right. In case you ever need it, I wrote an extension for it. Get Foggyline_SearchOrder (free Magento extension) from GitHub. Extension enables you to set the sort order of attributes used on the Catalog Advanced Search page. You can do so by configuring the available extension options under System > Configuration > Catalog > Catalog > Foggyline | Catalog Advanced Search - Attribute Sort Order like shown on the following image. [caption id="attachment_242" align="alignnone" width="876"] Foggyline_SearchOrder - Change the search order of attributes on Catalog Advanced Search page[/caption] And the resulting Catalog Advanced Search page as shown in the following image. Hope you find it useful. Cheers.

item.title: How to backup and restore Magento database
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Like most of the eCommerce applications, Magento stores its data into the database, more specifically MySQL database. Backing up your databases is extremely important so that you can recover your data and be up and running again in case problems occur. Problems such as system crashes, hardware failures, or users deleting data by mistake can turn your day into a real nightmare. There are several ways you can approach backing up your database in Magento, such as using official MySQL mysqldump tool, or doing it through Magento itself via its built in core Mage_Backup extension functionality. MySQL itself offers a variety of backup strategies. For instance if you are in discussion with hard core MySQL DB admin, you are bound to touch the terms such as: logical vs. physical backup, full vs. incremental backups, recovery methods, point-in-time recovery, backup scheduling, compression, encryption, etc. Physical backups are basically raw copies of files and directories that store the database contents. They are suitable for large databases that need to be recovered quickly. Logical backups are basically the information stored in your database such as structure (CREATE DATABASE, CREATE TABLE statements) and content (INSERT statements, or CSV files). If you are just the developer whose prime goal is to code the app, and database backups are the required little necessity, then you might lean to simply using the MySQL mysqldump tool doing the logical backups and not burdening your self with anything more than that. Backing up Magento database, or any other MySQL database for that matter, is extremely simple with mysqldump tool used via console/terminal. The SQL/CSV format backup/restore - here the content is dumped into the CSV file, while the structure is dumped into the SQL file. 
mysqldump --host=localhost --user='YOUR_USERNAME_HERE' --password='YOUR_PASSWORD_HERE' --default-character-set=utf8 --events --routines --dump-date --fields-terminated-by=',' --fields-enclosed-by='"' --fields-escaped-by='\\' --lines-terminated-by='\r\n' --tab=/var --log-error=/var/error.log YOUR_DB_NAME_HERE
The benefit of this type of backup is that you get each of the database table data in CSV format so you can easily load it into spreadsheet application like MS Excel or Open Office Calc, etc. The drawback of this type of backup is that it extremely time consuming to do restore, since you have to do LOAD DATA INFILE for each of the CSV files. To restore the database from this type of backup you can use either mysql alone or combination of mysql and mysqlimport tools. Keep in mind that mysqlimport is just a command-line interface to the LOAD DATA INFILE SQL statement, so its basically the same as using just mysql. Basically its a multi step process in this case involving following commands/statements. 
mysql --host=localhost --user='YOUR_USERNAME_HERE' --password
use YOUR_DB_NAME_HERE;

source /path/to/backup/table1.sql;
source /path/to/backup/table2.sql;
source /path/to/backup/tableN.sql;

LOAD DATA INFILE '/path/to/backup/table1.csv' INTO TABLE table1
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ',' ENCLOSED BY '"' ESCAPED BY '\\'
LINES TERMINATED BY '\r\n';

LOAD DATA INFILE '/path/to/backup/table2.csv' INTO TABLE table2
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ',' ENCLOSED BY '"' ESCAPED BY '\\'
LINES TERMINATED BY '\r\n';

LOAD DATA INFILE '/path/to/backup/table3.csv' INTO TABLE table3
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ',' ENCLOSED BY '"' ESCAPED BY '\\'
LINES TERMINATED BY '\r\n';

LOAD DATA INFILE '/path/to/backup/tableN.csv' INTO TABLE tableN
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ',' ENCLOSED BY '"' ESCAPED BY '\\'
LINES TERMINATED BY '\r\n';
Depending on how many tables you had in your database you can expect that many LOAD DATA INFILE statements. This is why this type of backup is not that practical for Magento (lots of tables), unless there is a good reason for it and you possibly have it scripted. The SQL format backup - here the structure and content are dumped into the SQL file. This is probably the most preferred type of backup for any PHP developer. 
mysqldump --host=localhost --user='YOUR_USERNAME_HERE' --password='YOUR_PASSWORD_HERE' --default-character-set=utf8 --events --routines --dump-date --log-error=/var/error.log YOUR_DB_NAME_HERE > DB_`date +"%Y%m%dT%H%M"`_BACKUP.sql
Additionally, you can chain / pipe command for compressing the SQL file into GZIP format, as shown below (my personal favourite backup command). 
mysqldump --host=localhost --user='YOUR_USERNAME_HERE' --password='YOUR_PASSWORD_HERE' --default-character-set=utf8 --events --routines --dump-date --log-error=/var/error.log YOUR_DB_NAME_HERE | gzip -9 > /path/to/backup/folder/DB_`date +"%Y%m%dT%H%M"`_BACKUP.sql.gz
Notice how both commands contain the %Y%m%dT%H%M part, this is just for the convenience so that we get the file with the timestamp in the file name. Also, as a security precaution you might omit the actual password from the command, just by calling the password parameter but not passing any value to it, like shown below. Doing so will show a MySQL prompt asking you for password entry before the actual dump is done. 
mysqldump --host=localhost --user='YOUR_USERNAME_HERE' --password --default-character-set=utf8 --events --routines --dump-date --log-error=/var/error.log YOUR_DB_NAME_HERE | gzip -9 > /path/to/backup/folder/DB_`date +"%Y%m%dT%H%M"`_BACKUP.sql.gz
This type of backup is extremely easy to restore, as entire backup is just one SQL file. 
mysql --host=localhost --user='YOUR_USERNAME_HERE' --password
use YOUR_DB_NAME_HERE;
source /path/to/backup/DB_BACKUP.sql;
Or if you are on the unix/linux machine there is even a shorthand, like shown below. 
mysql --host=localhost --user='YOUR_USERNAME_HERE' --password YOUR_DB_NAME_HERE < /path/to/backup/DB_BACKUP.sql;
Unless you don't have a full access to MySQL server, but have access to mysqldump I strongly advise you to take advantage of it. Possibly script the process of periodically backing up the database several times a day, at regular intervals, storing 2-3 days old backups. Unless your database is really huge, this should be an insignificant impact on storage and the database load itself during the backup. Mage_Backup extension functionality - finally, there is one more option I would like to mentioned, but I personally do not prefer it. Magento it self comes with a database backup feature available under Magento admin area System > Tools > Backups menu like shown in the following screenshot. [caption id="attachment_276" align="alignnone" width="604"] Magento Database Backup Feature[/caption] Creating backups this way results in a database dumps under Magento var/backups/ folder. The reason I am not a big fan of it is simple; what happens when your database is so corrupt or broken that you cannot access the admin area? Then there is no point and click actions you can execute, so either way you need to manage around console. Needless to say, there is not much point in having backups if you plan on placing them on the same server that runs your MySQL, so be sure to have them pushed/uploaded to a safe storage. Hope this helps.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Learn a simple way of database backup and restore in order to secure your Magento database in case of failures.
How To - Backup and restore Magento database

item.title: Installing and configuring MySQL 5.6 on CentOS 6.5
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded: This short guide is about installing latest (as of time of this writing) MySQL community server (v5.6) on latest CentOS (v6.5) server. In my example I used CentOS minimal, more precisely this distribution ISO image CentOS-6.5-x86_64-minimal.iso. You can grab download the RPM package for Yum installer from official MySQL Yum Repository page. In case you are using the console, without GUI interface here is direct link for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 / Oracle Linux 6 (Architecture Independent), RPM Package you can use with wget command. wget http://repo.mysql.com/mysql-community-release-el6-5.noarch.rpm yum install mysql-server

I had 4 clients by now that needed it. I guess they saw a benefit in it. It does make a sense for certain products. item.title: Installing Solr 4.6 with Java 1.7 on CentOS 6.5
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
If you some from the world of eCommerce, I don't have to tell you how important role plays a good search functionality. One of the currently most popular open source eCommerce platforms, Magento, seriously lacks a good built in search engine. There is a reason for that, its not that trivial. However, some merchants simply cannot ignore this so they turn to solutions such as Solr. Solr (pronounced "solar") is an open source enterprise search platform from the Apache Lucene project. Full-text search, hit highlighting, faceted search, distributed search and index replication are part of Solr. This is what makes it a solid choice for integrations into eCommerce systems such as Magento. In a nutshell, Solr is an app/server run on top Jetty which is a pure Java-based HTTP (Web) server and Java Servlet container. Just for the reference:
  • Latest version of Solr at the time of this writing is 4.6.0.
  • Latest version of Java runtime (JRE) at the time of this writing is 7u45 (1.7.0_45).
  • Latest version of CentOS at the time of this writing is 6.5.
If you are a developer eager to dig into Solr, here are a few simple steps by which you can get it up and running, in lets say your virtual box powered by (lets say) CentOS. This article assumes you have a clean install of CentOS, no previous installations of Java runtimes. We start by checking the currently available Java runtimes in our CentOS yum repository. If you have a clean default install of CentOS minimal distribution, then you should have no Java runtime installed like shown on the screen below. Next we check for the available Java runtime versions in our yum repository. We can do so with following command on a console. 
yum search java | grep 'java-'
You should now see a screen like the one below. In this case we want to install the latest one. Following command tells the yum to install it for us. 
yum install java-1.7.0-openjdk.x86_64
First you will see the confirmation screen like the one shown below (just write in the "y" and click the enter). Once Java runtime is installed you should see a screen like the one below. Finally, type down the java again in the console and hit enter, you should now see a console output indicating that Java runtime is there in your system like shown below. Now that we have Java runtime installed, we go ahead and install wget tool, as we will use it to download Solr binary. Following command will install wget into CentOS. 
yum install wget
Once you confirm it and installation is done, typing wget on console and hitting enter should give us something like shown in the image below. Finally we are able to download Solr binary package. Following command will download Solr binary to the directory you are currently in within your console. 
wget http://ftp.carnet.hr/misc/apache/lucene/solr/4.6.0/solr-4.6.0.tgz
Please note that the ftp.carnet.hr is an link from mirror server from Croatia. Can easily be any other server. Once the download is complete, you need to unpack the archive. 
tar -xzf solr-4.6.0.tgz
This should dump all of the archive content into the solr-4.6.0 directory. Solr binary archive package comes with an example application that is already set and waiting for you to run it. 
cd solr-4.6.0/example/
java -jar start.jar
If you successfully followed the steps so far, you should now see a screen like the one below indicating Solr that Solr is running. You can easily stop it by pressing Ctrl + C. In my case, my virtual box has an IP address of 192.168.0.22, and Network interface set to bridget adapter, so I was able to automatically access it from my host operating system (SSH into it for example). When Solr is running you should be able to access it through your browser at a link like http://192.168.0.22:8983/solr/ (just replace the IP with yours appropriately). Also, within your virtual box, you might want to turn of the firewall if you are using it only for development purposes, as it might stand in a way of accessing your Solr from browser. To turn off the firewall in CentOS, just issue the following command into console. 
service iptables stop
Hope this helps.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Quick guide for Installing Solr 4.6 with Java 1.7 on CentOS 6.5 for development purposes.

item.title: Magento - "Your search returns no results" error
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Please note that there might be several reasons why you can experience "Your search returns no results" error message. In this article I will share my experience. Recently I have been working on a Magento powered web store with roughly 20k simple type products. This was Magento Community Edition version 1.7.0.2. After upgrading MySQL database form version 5.1 to version 5.6 web store started experiencing "Your search returns no results" error. At first I was positive it was due to the upgrade of the database, even more encouraged to believe so when I first googled the "Magento MySQL 5.1 5.6 upgrade" and got some results indicating possible issue with MySQL 5.6 itself (http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=70608). Outlining the possible workaround by doing the (to be executed within MySQL): 
set optimizer_switch='semijoin=off';
Doing this did not resolve my case, which implied getting hands dirty and doing some tracing on my own. After turning on full call stack and query logging I was able to analyse each and every SQL query sent to MySQL and its origin from within PHP code. lib/Varien/Db/Adapter/Pdo/Mysql.php 

//...
protected $_debug = true;
//...
protected $_logAllQueries = true;
//...
protected $_logCallStack = true;
Analysis revealed large amount of INSERTS (new stuff) into DB, for example there is 48 inserts for products into EAV tables like "INSERT INTO `catalog_product_entity_varchar`...". Making for total of 286 INSERT's for just product catalog_product_entity_* tables within 20-30 seconds time for which I logged them. I say "large amount" as this analysis was done on a frontend while no one was doing anything in the backend, at least not Magento admin area. SO basicaly there should have been no "INSERT INTO `catalog_product_entity_*" activity. Then there was also large amount of "DELETE FROM `catalogsearch_result`" statements, 96 of them. Please note that there is no WHERE clause to this DELETE so entire table content is deleted. Again, this is pretty large amount of deletes for something as this kind of table, as it holds the reference to previous search result. If you search "blue" and Magento finds some results, it holds a reference to them here, and if you come to this table and truncate it, and do the same "blue" search again you will get "Your search returns no results" error. Following is the entire call stack that triggered this "DELETE FROM `catalogsearch_result`" statement. 

## 2014-01-17 07:55:14
## 38623 ## QUERY
SQL: DELETE FROM `catalogsearch_result`
AFF: 0
TIME: 0.0002
TRACE: #1 Varien_Db_Adapter_Pdo_Mysql#000000006ce0eb7f00000000e68c0313#->_debugStat(2, 'DELETE FROM `cat...', array(), &Varien_Db_Statement_Pdo_Mysql#000000006ce0e9c900000000e68c0313#) called at [lib/Varien/Db/Adapter/Pdo/Mysql.php:424]

#22 Mage_Api_Model_Server_V2_Handler#000000006ce0eb6900000000e68c0313#->catalogProductUpdate('6e059550683540d0...', 38954, &stdClass#000000006ce0ebb300000000e68c0313#, 'default', 'simple')
#23 SoapServer#000000006ce0ebb400000000e68c0313#->handle('handle() called at [app/code/core/Mage/Api/Model/Server/V2/Adapter/Soap.php:71]
#25 Mage_Api_Model_Server_V2_Adapter_Soap#000000006ce0eb3f00000000e68c0313#->run() called at [app/code/core/Mage/Api/Model/Server.php:138]
#26 Mage_Api_Model_Server#000000006ce0eb5500000000e68c0313#->run() called at [app/code/core/Mage/Api/controllers/V2/SoapController.php:46]
#27 Mage_Api_V2_SoapController#000000006ce0eb1e00000000e68c0313#->indexAction() called at [app/code/core/Mage/Core/Controller/Varien/Action.php:419]
#28 Mage_Api_V2_SoapController[Mage_Core_Controller_Varien_Action]#000000006ce0eb1e00000000e68c0313#->dispatch('index') called at [app/code/core/Mage/Core/Controller/Varien/Router/Standard.php:250]
#29 Mage_Core_Controller_Varien_Router_Standard#000000006ce0eb0e00000000e68c0313#->match(&Mage_Core_Controller_Request_Http#000000006ce0eb0900000000e68c0313#) called at [app/code/core/Mage/Core/Controller/Varien/Front.php:176]
#30 Mage_Core_Controller_Varien_Front#000000006ce0eb5300000000e68c0313#->dispatch() called at [app/code/core/Mage/Core/Model/App.php:354]
#31 Mage_Core_Model_App#000000006ce0eb2000000000e68c0313#->run(array('scope_code' => '', 'scope_type' => 'store', 'options' => array())) called at [app/Mage.php:683]
#32 Mage::run('', 'store') called at [index.php:88]
The real clue was actually this Mage_CatalogSearch_Model_Fulltext#000000006ce0e9aa00000000e68c0313#->rebuildIndex. Connecting the dots was actually easy, large number of product table related INSERT's (product saves) was triggering "Product Flat Data" indexer, accompanied by the "Catalog Search Index" indexer. Reindexing on the server did not took much, just a few seconds for "Catalog Search Index". This quickly reminded me on a external 3rd party warehouse service that had full Magento API access and was constantly pushing products to API. After the upgrade of MySQL to 5.6 we did a bit of performance optimisation tweaks to the database that made it significantly faster, which I guess the 3rd party service took advantage of and started pushing products more frequent. Solution was pretty simple, zero coding, we just switched "Product Flat Data" and "Catalog Search Index" indexer from "Update on Save" to "Manual Update" mode and set a cron that triggered these two reindexes every 3 hours. This enabled the longer term persistence of catalogsearch_result table, so there was no "Your search returns no results" message on the frontend. Hope this experience helps someone.

item.title: Pre-Warming the Magento Cache (pure console commands)
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
If you are using a Magento site with lots of products and categories, chances are you are using some sort of content caching. Usually, content is cached the first time customer opens a given URL, weather it is a category or product page. On a heavy load site, this first hit can take up to 10-20 seconds or even more. Once the content is cached, after that first hit, it gets severed pretty fast. So the idea is to pre-warm the cache somehow in order to avoid the unlucky customer doing it for the first time. Here are the two versions of cache pre-warming commands I wrote. Depending on the situation you are in, you might find the first one more convenient as it uses the Magento log_* tables to actually see what URLs have been visited mostly in near past and then triggers just those URLs.

Magento log_* tables based cache pre-warming

mysql --user="YOUR-DB-USERNAME-HERE" --password="YOUR-DB-PASSWORD-HERE" --skip-column-names -e "USE YOUR-DB-NAME-HERE; SELECT DISTINCT url FROM log_url JOIN log_url_info ON log_url.url_id = log_url_info.url_id WHERE url NOT LIKE '%.jpg%' AND url NOT LIKE '%.png%' AND url NOT LIKE '%.gif%' AND url NOT LIKE '%.css%' AND url NOT LIKE '%.js%' AND url NOT LIKE '%/uenc/%' AND url NOT LIKE '%/cart/%' AND url NOT LIKE '%?%' ORDER BY visit_time DESC;" | wget --spider --no-http-keep-alive --no-cache --wait=3 --append-output=warmup.log -i -
Please note the last "-" character in the command above. This is not a typo, its merely a options parameter specifying that URLs are read from the standard input, which is a piped to mysql command result. The mysql ORDER BY is not really necessary, its here just to force the order of things, as it makes sense to warm up the highest used pages first. The downside of this type of pre-warming is that it relies on past visits. In case you have a site which uses some frequent product imports/creations, these would obviously get skipped as the customer never had chance to visit them so they never end up in log_* tables.

Magento core_url_rewrite table based cache pre-warming

mysql --user="YOUR-DB-USERNAME-HERE" --password="YOUR-DB-PASSWORD-HERE" --skip-column-names -e "USE YOUR-DB-NAME-HERE; SELECT DISTINCT CONCAT('http://YOUR-SITE-DOMAIN-HERE/', request_path) FROM core_url_rewrite WHERE (category_id IS NOT NULL) OR (product_id IS NOT NULL);" | wget --spider --no-http-keep-alive --no-cache --append-output=warmup.log -i -
This approach is far more suitable for full warm-up, the only downside is that it can take some time to execute in case you have a store with large number of products and/or categories. Also, be sure to do a full "Catalog URL Rewrites" re-index under "System > Index Management" area of Magento admin. Please note, in order for the above two commands to work, be sure to replace all of the instances of "YOUR-*****-HERE" with your proper values. Hope this helps.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: magento, cache, warm, pre-warm, unix, linux, command, url, rewrite, log, table
Two simple unix / linux commands (mysql and wget based) for pre-warming Magento cache.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Very nice Branko, thanks for sharing :)

Enterprise does offer a cache-pre warmer built-in in the early mornings, I usually bump this up to 2 crawlers to make sure it happens quickly. However CE with no FPC doesn't have it built-in.
A more simplistic approach is the -r option in wget.
wget -r -l4 –spider -D thesite.com http://www.thesite.com
Recursive, 4 levels deep, spider (don't download), and only crawl sub links on thesite.com, you could also just point to the category sitemap in default magento and let it crawl this without the need of SQL.
Also, you can use wget [options] url & wget [options] url & ... to allow for multiple connections (must faster traversing than a single wget).
Anyhow, thanks for sharing it. It is an interesting approach I've not seen done before!
Thanks for the feedback, appreciate it!
[…] Ajzele gab Tipps zum Cache-Pre-Warming in der Community […]

Thank you for sharing! We wrote small crawler that is recursive as well but is ignoring external links. For some reason the two wgets were also necessary for the Magento Enterprise Full-Page-Cache to actually fill the cache. The solution was a shell-script with this three lines:
wget -O - subdomain.test.de/site.html | grep -o '<a href="http[^"]*"' | sed 's/<a href="//;s/"$//' | grep "subdomain.test.de" | while read line; do wget -P /tmp/warmup/output --delete-after $line done
Details (in German) are available here: http://www.code4business.de/magento-full-page-cache-warmup/

item.title: Up-sells, Cross-sells and Related Products in Magento (merchant / developer overview)
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Magento platform features several ways to promote your products. Options for presenting additional products in order to increase conversion rates and for providing various discounts and promotions make it really flexible and merchant friendly. In this article I will showcase three basic, built-in and sometimes misused features of Magento's so called promotions functionality: Up-sells, Cross-sells and Related Products.

Up-sells

Up-sells are products / items which are part of sales technique where you induce the customer purchase more expensive items, upgrades, or other add-ons in an attempt to make a more profitable sale. Up-selling implies selling something that is more profitable / preferable for the seller instead of the original sale. One example of up-selling would be a seller suggesting a customer to purchase more RAM or a larger hard drive when servicing his or her computer. As a part of the default Magento theme, these appear on the product info page as the one shown below. [caption id="attachment_369" align="alignnone" width="582"] Magento Up-sells[/caption] [ Merchant ] To set up up-sell products:
  1. Log in to the Magento admin
  2. Navigate to Catalog > Manage Products
  3. Find the product to which you want to add Up-sells
  4. Select and edit this product
  5. Select the Up-sells tab. This should bring up the screen like the one shown below. [caption id="attachment_376" align="alignnone" width="604"] Magento Up-sells admin area[/caption]
  6. From the products grid that appears, check any products you would like to mark as Up-sells
  7. Once a product has been checked, the Position shows up. You can optionally play with it in order to determine the exact sort order of the Up-sells in the product's page
  8. Press Save button
  9. You are done! Navigate to the front-end and check out your newly created Upsells block! (should be in a product info page like the one marked in image above)
[ Developer ] Template/Layout/Block/Collection references for up-sell products Up-sells are rendered using catalog/product/list/upsell.phtml template as shown below (with System > Configuration > Advanced > Developer > Debug > Template Path Hints > Yes). [caption id="attachment_386" align="alignnone" width="648"] magento-up-sells-template[/caption] Now, if you do a find/search of "catalog/product/list/upsell.phtml" within theme layout folder you will find that the app/design/frontend/base/default/layout/catalog.xml is layout file defining the block within the catalog_product_view handle as follows. 

	4
	upsell4
With basic Magento knowledge you can easily conclude / find out that block type "catalog/product_list_upsell" equals to Mage_Catalog_Block_Product_List_Upsell class found in app/code/core/Mage/Catalog/Block/Product/List/Upsell.php file. Now that we know the class behind the catalog/product/list/upsell.phtml template, we know that each reference to $this is actually a reference to instance of Mage_Catalog_Block_Product_List_Upsell class. Tracing further down the Mage_Catalog_Block_Product_List_Upsell class we can see that the actual up-sells collection is pulled from the product object itself as shown below. 
$product->getUpSellProductCollection();
Since $product is further instance of Mage_Catalog_Model_Product class, we find the actual getUpSellProductCollection method/function defined there within the app/code/core/Mage/Catalog/Model/Product.php file. However, given the Magento event/observer architecture we need to keep a broad view on things, since certain event observers can be triggered to modify the collections. What we are interested in this case is the actual SQL query that goes onto the server and that's behind our catalog/product/list/upsell.phtml template file. So if we quickly edit the catalog/product/list/upsell.phtml template file just to add a line of code like following on the top. 
getItemCollection()->getSelect(); exit; ?>
This will give you the following output on the product view page. 
SELECT 1 AS `status`, `e`.`entity_id`, `e`.`type_id`, `e`.`attribute_set_id`, `price_index`.`price`, `price_index`.`tax_class_id`, `price_index`.`final_price`, IF(price_index.tier_price IS NOT NULL, LEAST(price_index.min_price, price_index.tier_price), price_index.min_price) AS `minimal_price`, `price_index`.`min_price`, `price_index`.`max_price`, `price_index`.`tier_price`, `e`.`name`, `e`.`price`, `e`.`small_image`, `e`.`tax_class_id`, `e`.`url_key`, `e`.`thumbnail`, `e`.`short_description`, `e`.`special_price`, `e`.`special_from_date`, `e`.`special_to_date`, `e`.`news_from_date`, `e`.`news_to_date`, `e`.`required_options`, `e`.`price_type`, `e`.`weight_type`, `e`.`price_view`, `e`.`shipment_type`, `e`.`image_label`, `e`.`small_image_label`, `e`.`thumbnail_label`, `e`.`links_purchased_separately`, `e`.`msrp_enabled`, `e`.`msrp_display_actual_price_type`, `e`.`msrp`, `e`.`links_exist`, `e`.`cities`, `cat_index`.`position` AS `cat_index_position`, `links`.`link_id`, `link_attribute_position_int`.`value` AS `position` FROM `catalog_product_flat_1` AS `e` INNER JOIN `catalog_product_index_price` AS `price_index` ON price_index.entity_id = e.entity_id AND price_index.website_id = '1' AND price_index.customer_group_id = 0 INNER JOIN `catalog_category_product_index` AS `cat_index` ON cat_index.product_id=e.entity_id AND cat_index.store_id='1' AND cat_index.visibility IN(2, 4) AND cat_index.category_id = '3' INNER JOIN `catalog_product_link` AS `links` ON links.linked_product_id = e.entity_id AND links.link_type_id = 4 LEFT JOIN `catalog_product_link_attribute_int` AS `link_attribute_position_int` ON link_attribute_position_int.link_id = links.link_id AND link_attribute_position_int.product_link_attribute_id = '3' WHERE (e.entity_id NOT IN((SELECT `sales_flat_quote_item`.`product_id` FROM `sales_flat_quote_item` WHERE (quote_id = '')))) AND (links.product_id = 44) AND (e.entity_id != '44') ORDER BY `position` ASC LIMIT 4
This SQL query, executed on a non-optimized/developer machine with a clean Magento CE 1.8.1.0 + 120 products sample data took around 0,016 seconds. Finally, if your custom theme requires removal of up-sells, you can do so easily just by adding the following to your theme local.xml layout file.

Cross-sells

Cross-sell products are similar to impulse purchases next to the cash register in the checkout line of a grocery store. In Magento products offered as a cross-sell appear on the shopping cart page just before the customer begins the checkout process. One example of cross-selling would be a laptop seller offering a customer a mouse, pen-drive, and or accessories. As a part of the default Magento theme, these appear on the shopping cart page as the one shown below. [caption id="attachment_370" align="alignnone" width="604"] Magento Cross-sell[/caption] [ Merchant ] To set up cross-sell products:
  1. Log in to the Magento admin
  2. Navigate to Catalog > Manage Products
  3. Find the product you want to add cross-sells to
  4. Select and edit this product
  5. Select the Cross-sells tab. This should bring up the screen like the one shown below. [caption id="attachment_380" align="alignnone" width="604"] Magento Cross-sell admin area[/caption]
  6. From the products grid that appears, check any products you would like to mark as cross-sells
  7. Once a product has been checked, the Position shows up. You can optionally play with it in order to determine the exact sort order of the cross-sells in the shopping cart. If you have multiple products in the cart they are randomly selected, so the sort order will not take effect.
  8. Press Save button
  9. In the front-end, add the product you just edited to the shopping cart.
  10. In the shopping cart you should now be able to see the cross-sells in the cross-sell block as in the shopping cart page image above
[ Developer ] Template/Layout/Block/Collection references for cross-sell products Cross-sell products products are rendered using checkout/cart/crosssell.phtml template as shown below (with System > Configuration > Advanced > Developer > Debug > Template Path Hints > Yes). [caption id="attachment_406" align="alignnone" width="615"] crosssell-front-path-hint[/caption] If you do a find/search of "checkout/cart/crosssell.phtml" within theme layout folder you will find that the app/design/frontend/base/default/layout/checkout.xml is layout file defining the block within the checkout_cart_index handle as follows.
Block type "checkout/cart_crosssell" equals to Mage_Checkout_Block_Cart_Crosssell class found in app/code/core/Mage/Checkout/Block/Cart/Crosssell.php file. Now that we know the class behind the checkout/cart/crosssell.phtml template, we know that each reference to $this is actually a reference to instance of Mage_Checkout_Block_Cart_Crosssell class. Tracing further down the Mage_Checkout_Block_Cart_Crosssell class we can see that the actual cross-sell products collection is assembled within the getItems() method which does all sort of filtering and checks, one of which is currently added products to cart. What we are interested in this case is the actual SQL query that goes onto the server and that's behind our checkout/cart/crosssell.phtml template file. In this case we will quickly edit (and then undo) the core Mage_Checkout_Block_Cart_Crosssell class by adding the following to its getItems() method somewhere after the collection has been instantiated. 
getSelect(); exit; ?>
This will give you the following output on the product view page. 
SELECT 1 AS `status`, `e`.`entity_id`, `e`.`type_id`, `e`.`attribute_set_id`, `price_index`.`price`, `price_index`.`tax_class_id`, `price_index`.`final_price`, IF(price_index.tier_price IS NOT NULL, LEAST(price_index.min_price, price_index.tier_price), price_index.min_price) AS `minimal_price`, `price_index`.`min_price`, `price_index`.`max_price`, `price_index`.`tier_price`, `e`.`name`, `e`.`price`, `e`.`small_image`, `e`.`tax_class_id`, `e`.`url_key`, `e`.`thumbnail`, `e`.`short_description`, `e`.`special_price`, `e`.`special_from_date`, `e`.`special_to_date`, `e`.`news_from_date`, `e`.`news_to_date`, `e`.`required_options`, `e`.`price_type`, `e`.`weight_type`, `e`.`price_view`, `e`.`shipment_type`, `e`.`image_label`, `e`.`small_image_label`, `e`.`thumbnail_label`, `e`.`links_purchased_separately`, `e`.`msrp_enabled`, `e`.`msrp_display_actual_price_type`, `e`.`msrp`, `e`.`links_exist`, `e`.`cities`, `cat_index`.`position` AS `cat_index_position`, `at_inventory_in_stock`.`is_in_stock` AS `inventory_in_stock`, `links`.`link_id`, `link_attribute_position_int`.`value` AS `position` FROM `catalog_product_flat_1` AS `e` INNER JOIN `catalog_product_index_price` AS `price_index` ON price_index.entity_id = e.entity_id AND price_index.website_id = '1' AND price_index.customer_group_id = 0 INNER JOIN `catalog_category_product_index` AS `cat_index` ON cat_index.product_id=e.entity_id AND cat_index.store_id='1' AND cat_index.visibility IN(2, 4) AND cat_index.category_id = '3' INNER JOIN `cataloginventory_stock_item` AS `at_inventory_in_stock` ON (at_inventory_in_stock.`product_id`=e.entity_id) AND ((at_inventory_in_stock.use_config_manage_stock = 0 AND at_inventory_in_stock.manage_stock=1 AND at_inventory_in_stock.is_in_stock=1) OR (at_inventory_in_stock.use_config_manage_stock = 0 AND at_inventory_in_stock.manage_stock=0) OR (at_inventory_in_stock.use_config_manage_stock = 1 AND at_inventory_in_stock.is_in_stock=1)) INNER JOIN `catalog_product_link` AS `links` ON links.linked_product_id = e.entity_id AND links.link_type_id = 5 LEFT JOIN `catalog_product_link_attribute_int` AS `link_attribute_position_int` ON link_attribute_position_int.link_id = links.link_id AND link_attribute_position_int.product_link_attribute_id = '4' WHERE (links.product_id IN ('44')) AND (links.linked_product_id NOT IN ('44')) GROUP BY `e`.`entity_id` ORDER BY `position` ASC LIMIT 4
This SQL query, also took around 0,016 seconds. Finally, if your custom theme requires removal of cross-sell products, you can do so easily just by adding the following to your theme local.xml layout file.

Related Products

Related products are meant to be purchased in addition to the item the customer is viewing. As a part of the default Magento theme, these appear in the right column of the product info page as the one shown below. [caption id="attachment_371" align="alignnone" width="582"] Magento Related-Products[/caption] [ Merchant ] To set up related products:
  1. Log in to the Magento admin
  2. Navigate to
  3. Catalog > Manage Products
  4. Find the product you want to add related items to
  5. Select this product to load it for editing
  6. Select the Related Products tab. This should bring up the screen like the one shown below.
  7. From the products grid that appears, check any products you would like to mark as related.
  8. Once a product has been checked, the Position shows up. You can optionally play with it in order to determine the exact sort order of of the related products on the main product's page
  9. Press Save button
  10. You are done! Navigate to the front-end and check out your newly created Related products block as in the product info page image above
[ Developer ] Template/Layout/Block/Collection references for related products Related products are rendered using catalog/product/list/related.phtml template as shown below (with System > Configuration > Advanced > Developer > Debug > Template Path Hints > Yes). [caption id="attachment_404" align="alignnone" width="401"] magento-related-path-hints[/caption] Now, if you do a find/search of "catalog/product/list/related.phtml" within theme layout folder you will find that the app/design/frontend/base/default/layout/catalog.xml is layout file defining the block within the catalog_product_view handle as follows.
Block type "catalog/product_list_related" equals to Mage_Catalog_Block_Product_List_Related class found in app/code/core/Mage/Catalog/Block/Product/List/Related.php file. Now that we know the class behind the catalog/product/list/related.phtml template, we know that each reference to $this is actually a reference to instance of Mage_Catalog_Block_Product_List_Related class. Tracing further down the Mage_Catalog_Block_Product_List_Related class we can see that the actual related products collection is pulled from the product object itself as shown below. 
$product->getRelatedProductCollection();
Since $product is further instance of Mage_Catalog_Model_Product class, we find the actual getRelatedProductCollection method/function defined there within the app/code/core/Mage/Catalog/Model/Product.php file. What we are interested in this case is the actual SQL query that goes onto the server and that's behind our catalog/product/list/related.phtml template file. So if we quickly edit the catalog/product/list/related.phtml template file just to add a line of code like following on the top. 
getItems()->getSelect(); exit; ?>
This will give you the following output on the product view page. 
SELECT 1 AS `status`, `e`.`entity_id`, `e`.`type_id`, `e`.`attribute_set_id`, `e`.`required_options`, `price_index`.`price`, `price_index`.`tax_class_id`, `price_index`.`final_price`, IF(price_index.tier_price IS NOT NULL, LEAST(price_index.min_price, price_index.tier_price), price_index.min_price) AS `minimal_price`, `price_index`.`min_price`, `price_index`.`max_price`, `price_index`.`tier_price`, `e`.`name`, `e`.`price`, `e`.`small_image`, `e`.`tax_class_id`, `e`.`url_key`, `e`.`thumbnail`, `e`.`short_description`, `e`.`special_price`, `e`.`special_from_date`, `e`.`special_to_date`, `e`.`news_from_date`, `e`.`news_to_date`, `e`.`required_options`, `e`.`price_type`, `e`.`weight_type`, `e`.`price_view`, `e`.`shipment_type`, `e`.`image_label`, `e`.`small_image_label`, `e`.`thumbnail_label`, `e`.`links_purchased_separately`, `e`.`msrp_enabled`, `e`.`msrp_display_actual_price_type`, `e`.`msrp`, `e`.`links_exist`, `e`.`cities`, `cat_index`.`position` AS `cat_index_position`, `links`.`link_id`, `link_attribute_position_int`.`value` AS `position`, `link_attribute_qty_decimal`.`value` AS `qty` FROM `catalog_product_flat_1` AS `e` INNER JOIN `catalog_product_index_price` AS `price_index` ON price_index.entity_id = e.entity_id AND price_index.website_id = '1' AND price_index.customer_group_id = 0 INNER JOIN `catalog_category_product_index` AS `cat_index` ON cat_index.product_id=e.entity_id AND cat_index.store_id='1' AND cat_index.visibility IN(2, 4) AND cat_index.category_id = '3' INNER JOIN `catalog_product_link` AS `links` ON links.linked_product_id = e.entity_id AND links.link_type_id = 1 LEFT JOIN `catalog_product_link_attribute_int` AS `link_attribute_position_int` ON link_attribute_position_int.link_id = links.link_id AND link_attribute_position_int.product_link_attribute_id = '2' LEFT JOIN `catalog_product_link_attribute_decimal` AS `link_attribute_qty_decimal` ON link_attribute_qty_decimal.link_id = links.link_id AND link_attribute_qty_decimal.product_link_attribute_id = '6' WHERE (e.entity_id NOT IN((SELECT `sales_flat_quote_item`.`product_id` FROM `sales_flat_quote_item` WHERE (quote_id = '8')))) AND (links.product_id = 44) AND (e.entity_id != '44') ORDER BY `position` ASC
This SQL query, also took around 0,016 seconds. Finally, if your custom theme requires removal of related products, you can do so easily just by adding the following to your theme local.xml layout file.

item.title: Setting up Magento with Amazon CloudFront CDN
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Amazon CloudFront is a content delivery web service (CDN), delivering low latency web content like images, css and js files. All content requests are automatically routed to the nearest location of a visitor, which helps to reduce the latency during data transfer. This is achieved by using a global network of edge locations for content delivery. If you are running a high traffic web shop, especially the one with high(er) quality images, you might consider using a CDN. Amazon prices seem pretty affordable. You can use their Simple Monthly Calendar to calculate the average cost. To setup Magento with Amazon CloudFront CDN, we first need to setup the CloudFront itself. Login to your Amazon console https://console.aws.amazon.com/console/home like shown below. [caption id="attachment_416" align="alignnone" width="604"] Amazon console interface[/caption] Once logged in, click on Storage & Content Delivery > CloudFront link, this will get you to a screen like shown below. [caption id="attachment_417" align="alignnone" width="604"] Amazon CloudFront new distribution creation[/caption] Unless you already have existing distribution, you need to create a new one clicking on the "Create Distribution" button like marked on the image above. Once clicked, the following interface comes up. [caption id="attachment_418" align="alignnone" width="604"] Amazon content web delivery method[/caption] In this case, we are interested in Web as a delivery method for our content. Check the "Web" and click on the Continue button. This will bring you to a distribution settings screen like shown on the screenshots below. [caption id="attachment_420" align="alignnone" width="604"] Amazon distribution setting screen[/caption] [caption id="attachment_419" align="alignnone" width="604"] Amazon distribution setting screen[/caption] Notice the Origin Domain Name value, which in my example is set to my test web shop domain (magento-ce-17.foggyline.net). Value Origin ID is a freely assigned per distribution unique value; something meaningful to describe your origin (your web shop domain). Once you are done configuring the rest of the options as per your preference, click on the Create Distribution button. This will get you to the screen like the one shown below. [caption id="attachment_422" align="alignnone" width="604"] Amazon CloudFront distribution creation in progress[/caption] It takes roughly ten minutes for distribution to be created; that is for its Status to change from In Progress to Deployed. Once distribution is deployed, you can take a copy-paste of the Domain Name value like shown below; which in my case is diiqy9eqglu2g.cloudfront.net. Once you got hold of Domain Name value, its time to get back to Magento. As a first step, I strongly suggest you open up a frontend of your web shop, open up a category product listing page, right click on any image and do the Copy Image URL from your browser. For example, if your image URL is like the one shown below, try copy-pasting it into another tab in your browser. You should be able to see the image just fine. 
http://magento-ce-17.foggyline.net/media/catalog/product/cache/1/small_image/135x/9df78eab33525d08d6e5fb8d27136e95/h/t/htc-touch-diamond.jpg
Now open up another tab in your browser, copy-paste the same URL to it, but this time replace your domain with Amazon CloudFront Domain Name value like shown below. 
http://diiqy9eqglu2g.cloudfront.net/media/catalog/product/cache/1/small_image/135x/9df78eab33525d08d6e5fb8d27136e95/h/t/htc-touch-diamond.jpg
Opening that URL in the browser should return the same image. This is your confirmation that your CloudFront distribution is working nicely with your origin. Now you are ready to make the necessary changes in Magento. Login to Magento admin, go to System > Configuration > General > Web > [ Unsecure | Secure ] sections and modify the Base Skin URL, Base Media URL, Base JavaScript URL options to reflect your Amazon CloudFront Domain Name value like shown in the example screen below. [caption id="attachment_424" align="alignnone" width="904"] Magento URL settings[/caption] Even though this example, sets the Base Skin URL, Base Media URL, Base JavaScript URL values on Current Configuration Scope > Default Config level; I strongly suggest you set them on individual website level. This will leave admin area pulling media content files from the original (your) server; which is not a bad idea in case something happens to your distribution, you want to be able to login smoothly in your admin area. With this we are (almost) done with the process of setting up Magento with Amazon CloudFront CDN. One more thing remains however; content invalidation. By default each edge location checks for an updated version of your file whenever it receives a request more than 24 hours after the previous time it checked the origin for changes to that file. This means that if a certain image changes on your (origin) server, the change wont be immediate on Amazon CloudFront. You can force the content invalidation yourself by using the Amazon CloudFront API. It usually takes 10 to 15 minutes for CloudFront to complete your invalidation request, depending on the size of the request. You may invalidate up to 1,000 files each month from Amazon CloudFront at no additional charge. Beyond the first 1,000 files, you will be charged per file for each file listed in your invalidation requests. To create an invalidation batch request, you do a POST request on certain URL. The request body must include an XML document with an InvalidationBatch element. 
POST /2013-11-22/distribution/distribution ID/invalidation HTTP/1.0
Host: cloudfront.amazonaws.com
Authorization: AWS authentication string
Content-Type: text/xml


   
      3
      
         /image1.jpg
         /image2.jpg
         /videos/movie.flv
      
   
   20120301090001
Luckily you don't have to write a single line of code, as others have already done it for you. mgt-commerce.com has a Magento extension (Mgt_CloudfrontInvalidation) just for that, you can get it from their website here, along with the instructions of how to use it. Hope this was helpful.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Quick guide on setting up Magento with Amazon CloudFront CDN. No actual extension needed, except for the invalidation part (if you choose to have one).
Setting up Magento with Amazon CloudFront CDN

item.title: Foggyline_Cctoolbar - free "configurable catalog toolbar" extension for Magento
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded: Recently I was working on a project that required some modifications around "Sort By" drop-down of catalog toolbar; which gave me an idea for this little extension. Free "configurable catalog toolbar" extension for Magento. This extension will allow you to do slight modifications to catalog toolbar, such as merge/combine "Sort by" and "order", custom labels for "Sort by", etc. This extension was originally built and tested on Magento CE v1.8.1.0. Really not much to it, just a minor modifications around toolbar, but ones you can do through admin area. Once installed, extension can be further configured under System > Configuration > Catalog > Catalog > Foggyline | Configurable catalog toolbar. By default extension output is disabled, until configuration option Enabled is set to Yes as shown in the image below. [caption id="attachment_435" align="alignnone" width="562"] Foggyline_Cctoolbar - Magento Extension Config[/caption] Screenshot below shows the result you get on the frontend area. [caption id="attachment_436" align="alignnone" width="604"] Foggyline_Cctoolbar - Magento Extension Frontend[/caption] Extension is available on GitHub here [Foggyline_Cctoolbar] for those who find it interesting.
