item.title: Magento "Translate Inline" feature for frontend string translations
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Magento is a multi-language eCommerce platform, among other things. Meaning it can support multiple languages through its multiple store concept. Each store presents one locale which further breaks down to language. Default Magento installation comes with en_US locale, meaning US variation of English language. Multi-language support is a highly important feature, even essential one, for most of the modern web shops. Unless you have specific reason to sell your goods only locally within the borders of your country. Even then there are resons to support multiple languages. Without further digging into the why and when, lets focus on how. How can we use Magento built in "Translate Inline" feature to speed up the project development and communication when it comes to the boring part of "can we change this string to say..." requests? Even though there is already so many articles on this topic, figured I'll give my overview. I'll be completely open and honest; the most boring part of Magento development for me is handling translation requests from client. Stuff like "can we change 'Shipping method' to 'Delivery method'" or "can we change 'Shipping' to 'Postage'..." are just plain old boring for every developer. In this case specific we are talking about en_US vs. en_GB locale, where the other one can be downloaded from Magento Connect and you are pretty well covered in terms of UK specific string. Sometimes however, there is more to it then just one language translate to another. Sometimes you simply wish to change the existing string, lets say "Hi %s" to "Welcome %s" or something like that. Usually, this is done by theme specific translation csv file. For example, if your theme is called foggy, you would place such translation file into app/design/frontend/default/foggy/locale/en_US/translate.csv as follows: 
"Hi %s","Welcome %s"
Given that this is sort of theme specific label change we wont be using across other projects, it makes sense to put it into translate.csv and not into default system wide locale csv files folder, which is app/locale/en_US/. Why do we need "Translate Inline" if we can just add stuff to translate.csv? Well, translation is not really a part of developer job, or it should not be, especially if its on a daily basis and bits and pieces approach. When you calculate in the fact that every change should go through version control system (like GIT), then deployed to staging / production. Changing simple string can come down to 15-20-30min of work from time you find its true form in class or template file, just to see it kick in on production server. How do you explain that cost to a client who is going after you with "hey, why am I seeing 3h billable hours on this weeks invoice for these 8 simple string changes, I thought Magento had this taken cared of...". Its kind of unreasonable to level up the cost of "just a data entry" with "custom development", but this is basically what you are doing with all those additional custom translations. Assuming these translation request did not come all at once, but one by one and you were in a position to push each individual to repository, deploy, etc. Really annoying, but these are the realistic cases, since some clients can take these requests to the extreme during the project development. As a developer you should only make sure that everything you code, every string that gets pushed to browser for customer / administrator to see, gets passed through translation function as shown below. If you can stick to that simple rule, my wild guess is that you are 80-90% covered with a help from "Translate Inline" feature. The rest of 10-20% comes down to various 3rd party extensions that you might have installed that do not follow this simple rule, or Magento code itself. 
__('Hello');

/* Available to be called from anywhere */
Mage::helper('core')->__('Hello');

?>
The way translate function works is that it will search for the string in following order:
  1. core_translate table of the database
  2. If no matching string is found in the core_translate table, Magento turns to translate.csv file within the active theme.
  3. If no matching string is found in translate.csv, Magento looks for one in locale folder under app/locale/en_US (where en_US in this case, could just the same be hr_Hr or whatever active locale is).
  4. If no matching string is found in locale folder, Magento uses the original string
As you can see, the first stop is core_translate table of the database, which is like saying Translate Inline takes precedence over all. Lets show some examples of this in action. We start by turning on the Translate Inline feature as follows:
  1. Login to your Magento administration area
  2. Go to System > Configuration > Advanced > Developer > Translate Inline Enabled for Frontend > [Yes] as shown on the image below. [caption id="attachment_443" align="alignnone" width="890"] Magento Translate Inline Config[/caption]
  3. Optionally if you are working on a live site, go to System > Configuration > Advanced > Developer > Developer Client Restrictions > Developer Client Restrictions. You might want to add your external IP address to the list (whatismyip.com) as shown below. [caption id="attachment_445" align="alignnone" width="870"] Magento Translate Inline Config[/caption]
  4. Go to frontend, you should see some strings circled in red, as shown below. [caption id="attachment_447" align="alignnone" width="969"] Magento Translate Incline Frontend[/caption]
If you now hover your mouse over any of those red circled labels you should see a little book icon appear on the lower left corner of a string like shown below. [caption id="attachment_449" align="alignnone" width="968"] Magento Translate Inline Frontend[/caption] If you now click on the book icon a popup should appear as shown below. [caption id="attachment_451" align="alignnone" width="968"] Magento Translate Inline Frontend[/caption] Several values are listed here. The one of highest interest to us are:
  • Original - which tells us what is the original string, the one in code, that we are translating. This will always remain the same, regardless of how many time we inline translation on it. Unless we change the string in code.
  • Store View Specific - might be a good option to check it always, even if you are running single store, the choice is yours.
  • Custom - the new string we want in place. The important thing here to keep in mind is that this string can be either simple string or formatted string supporting placeholders as shown below. [caption id="attachment_455" align="alignnone" width="969"] Magento Translate Inline Frontend[/caption]
Once you click the Submit button, AJAX request is made in the background to Mage_Core_AjaxController->translateAction() with proper array of parameters as shown below. [caption id="attachment_458" align="alignnone" width="800"] Magento Translate Inline - Charles Web Debugger[/caption] Once it hits the Mage_Core_AjaxController->translateAction(), the data is first sanitized as shown below. [caption id="attachment_460" align="alignnone" width="649"] Mage_Core_AjaxController[/caption] Posted data is further passed on to Mage_Core_Helper_Translate->apply() method as shown below. [caption id="attachment_461" align="alignnone" width="790"] Mage_Core_Helper_Translate[/caption] Which further calls the Mage_Core_Model_Translate_Inline->processAjaxPost() method as shown below. [caption id="attachment_462" align="alignnone" width="646"] Mage_Core_Model_Translate_Inline[/caption] Once entire save process is over, data is saved into core_translate table as shown below. [caption id="attachment_463" align="alignnone" width="604"] core_translate table[/caption] This should give you a pretty good view on things in case you ever need to programmatically add stuff to inline translation table. The funny thing is, once the successful AJAX response closes the popup, you need to reload the page in order to see the string change. In a nutshell, this is (mostly) all you need to know about Magento's Translate Inline feature. The general message is; as a developer you need to push your strings through translation functions, the rest is quick and easy :) NOTE: There seem to be some JavaScript errors appearing on some browsers when you use Translate Inline feature, even with the default Magento 1.8.1.0 installation. Worked for me without any issues in Firefox browser. Hope this helps.

item.title: Book review "Magento 1.8 Development Cookbook"
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Everyone new to Magento programming can tell you its massive. Everyone experienced in Magento programming will tell you the same thing. Nothing about Magento is cute and cuddly. It is highly modular eCommerce platform that empowers developer to do almost anything with it if he is knowledgeable enough. There are two ways to gain the knowledge, either by "do it your self" as most of us early adopters did in the first year(s) of Magento, or through books like this one. Magento 1.8 Development Cookbook was written by Bart Delvaux from Belgium and Nurul Ferdous from Bangladesh. Needless to say, after this both of them deserve a Follow on my/your Twitter account. The book is divided into 12 chapters spread across over 200 pages. Chapters cover following topics:
  • Chapter 1: Getting Started with Magento
  • Chapter 2: Theming
  • Chapter 3: Working with Products
  • Chapter 4: Creating a Module
  • Chapter 5: Database Concepts
  • Chapter 6: Database and Modules
  • Chapter 7: Magento Backend
  • Chapter 8: Event Handlers and Cronjobs
  • Chapter 9: Creating a Shipping Module
  • Chapter 10: Creating a Product Slider Widget
  • Chapter 11: Performance Optimization
  • Chapter 12: Debugging and Unit Testing
Chapter 1: Getting Started with Magento starts logically, as it guides you through preparing the development environment, installing Magento with sample data, adding version control to the source code, configuring the development tools. I especially liked the authors focus on version control tool, setting the right tone on development from the start. I only slightly disagree with the content of .gitignore file. But if you are just starting out with Magento its perfectly fine, later you might want to check various gists on github that give you more flexibility with this one. Overall, Chapter 1 comes as a nice intro/setup for what follows in a book. Chapter 2: Theming focuses on the visual side of Magento as it guides you through configuring Magento themes and packages, creating your first theme, adding extra files to your theme, adding jQuery support, changing a page title, working with translations, understanding the theming block system, adding widgets to the layout. Focusing on frontend right from the start is exactly the same approach I use in all my tutoring with newbie Magento developers. Besides the obvious point&click for theme configuration, developers are introduced with theme structure, template file, layout files, fall-back logic, etc. The only minus I would give authors for this chapter is the lack of deeper, focus on layout XML files. There is so many to talk about this, that it even deserves a special Layouts chapter. The rest however is pretty solid ground for fresh developers. Chapter 3: Working with Products turns to products, guiding you through setting up the catalog defaults, working with attribute sets, working with product types, adding a Facebook like button, adding a product to the cart through query string, embedding a YouTube video, changing the URL of a product page. To be honest my impressions on this chapter are kind if divided. Maybe all these years of Magento development took their toll, and I expect more from certain things. What tripped me of here is the focus on something that is not really a development but configuration. Dont get me wrong, this is configuration stuff that every Magento developer should know inside out. Its just that I was expecting primarily code related stuff in a cookbook. Besides that, second half of a chapter puts it on a right path. Think the part with adding a product to the cart through query string is really nice. Every second project I worked on required something like this, so its good to know, to avoid hours of code tracing. Its not much, but its nice to see it in there. Chapter 4: Creating a Module is about module development. As soon as I read the chapter title, my first reaction was, its not module, its an extension. Yea, I know, it makes no difference, but if Magento calls them extensions, all over the place, then lets get along with the terminology. Here, authors guide you through creating files, registering blocks, helpers, and models, adding a new page, adding a layout file, adding a translation file, adding a block of new products, rewriting a core class. I really like they have a special recipe just for adding the translation file to your extension. So many authors (sometimes me included) forgot to add translation files to their script, even just for en_US locale. Given that Magento supports multi-locale/multi-language its really a nice practice to do so. The recipe that really caught my eye is the last one in this chapter talking about rewriting a core class. Saying that "Unfortunately, in some cases it isn't possible to work with events. So, you need to rewrite a core class. In this case, you have to do it as described in this recipe" is not true in this case. Authors are rewriting a non-existing/magic-triggered method getName() on Mage_Catalog_Model_Product class. More valid approach would be to create an observer for catalog_product_load_after event and do the $observer->getEvent()->getProduct()->setName('Packt ' . $observer->getEvent()->getProduct()->getData('name')). Using rewrites is a big NO, unless and this is really unless there is a solid reason for it, and usually there is not. If two extensions rewrite the same core file, you have a problem, so don't use rewrites. Chapter 5: Database Concepts moves the focus to database as it guides you through finding your way in the tables, creating a database connection in Magento, working with flat tables, working with EAV tables, configuring a Master/Slave setup, repairing the database. Even though Magento tries to abstract everything directly database related, its invaluable to know how to work diretctly with database, grabbing the read/write connections, etc. This usually comes in play when you are working on high performance sites, and every millisecond of SQL query execution time counts. for example, custom logic for finding related products automatically based on some attribute value, etc. Sometimes Magento collection filters don't cut it as you end up with massive sql joins, etc. In situatons like these you might be better of with pure database connection and 2-3 custom SQL queries. Not really a Magento way, but high performance does not really care. Working with EAV tables does not quite do it justice, as the EAV section of Magento probably deserves its own book. I cannot express how happy I was seeing the MySQL replication recipe. Its not much, and in practice you will most likely have to consult additional documentation, but this one definetly deserves its place in Magento book. Chapter 6: Database and Modules sort of builds on top of previous chapter by guiding you through registering the resource models, registering connections, installing and upgrading scripts, creating a flat table with models, working with Magento collections. All of which are important concepts and need to know stuff. If you are a 3rd party extension developer sections like installing and upgrading scripts are invaluable. This section does not quite do it justice, as there is more to be told about it. Working with Magento collections section covers a lot of ground, but stays on sql AND only filtering. In practice you often need OR and other sql expressions. Understandably this alone would add few more pages to the book. Overall, nice introductory chapter for important basics every developer should know about extension / database communication. Chapter 7: Magento Backend takes us to admin area of Magento, in terms of backend code. It guides us through registering a backend controller, extending the menu, adding an ACL, extending the system configuration, creating a grid from a database table, adding customer attributes, working with source models. All of the sections covered are considered as a must know for every backend developer. I only slightly disagree on using the before xml attribute while registering the your admin router within config.xml. I prefer to be less obtrusive and future proof, if I can call it like that, by using the after. I would rather have my extension break in future when Magento adds controllers and/or controller actions in place where mine were. This way, your take precedence. Using before is like you are doing rewrite, in cases where Magento might have the same controllers and/or controller actions on path like yours. Besides this little thing, the rest is really valuable material. I especially liked the adding customer attributes section, as this one is so often the case in projects. Chapter 8: Event Handlers and Cronjobs takes a turn to the one and only, truly flexible and awesome part of Magento, events. It guides you through understanding Magento event types, creating your own event, adding an event listener, introducing cronjobs, creating a new cronjob, testing your new cronjob. I liked the part where authors do a quick modification of core file to do a Mage::log($eventName) to show you a quick way you can capture all events dispatch within the request. Really valuable tip. Unfortunately this chapter does not do it justice as there is so much more to be talked about events alone. For example the two types of event you have in system: "static" and "dynamic" ones, if I may call it like that. Dynamic one being all those which get their name during runtime as catalog_product_load_after which comes from Mage::dispatchEvent($this->_eventPrefix.'_load_before', $params);. Cronjobs related section do a pretty good job at explaing how it works. Chapter 9: Creating a Shipping Module spans across 14 pages, guiding you through initializing module configurations, writing an adapter model, extending the shipping method features, adding the module in the frontend. Glad to see entire chapter focused on one topic. Does a pretty good job at it. In practice, real world projects, custom shipping methods are usually more often than custom payment methods. Definelty something every Magento developer should have a good understanding of. Chapter 10: Creating a Product Slider Widget places a focus on a single slider thing, guiding you through creating an empty module, registering helpers and blocks, creating a widget configuration file, creating a block and the template files, creating a custom configuration parameter, finalizing the theming. It serves as a nice round-up for some of the stuff presented in a book so far. Not much to say about this one. Like the section on creating a custom configuration parameter, as it gives a nice "good practice" example on how your extensions should give some configuration parameters to admin users for more flexibility. Chapter 11: Performance Optimization jumps to performance topic, guiding you though exploring the limits of a website, optimizing the database and MySQL configuration, optimizing the Apache web server, tuning the Magento configurations, configuring APC and Memcached, optimizing the PHP configurations, analysing the page speed. Valuable stuff covered here. Definitely not a final list of optimisation tricks, but one that you should look into. I won't even comment this beyond, a must read! Chapter 12: Debugging and Unit Testing sort of goes back to the begging, next to preparing the development environment. It guides you through getting started with Xdebug, debugging with FirePHP, installing PHPUnit, creating a Magento test case. I honestly don't feel worthy to comment on this, as I never do a unit testing with Magento. There, I've said it, publicly. Not because I don't know how to do it, but because Magento wasn't built with unit testing in mind, various 3rd party extension don't come with unit tests, its hard enough to explain the costs of usual Magento development, not to mention development where you are hard to do a 100% code coverage (as in various 3rd party extension code). I cant say to my client, yes it unite tested while its not 100%, and I don't guaranty for 3rd party extension, etc. Either way, I welcome this chapter as a good to know, and nice to implement in practice. In my comments above I might have sound harsh for certain chapters. Please don't look at it as a reason not to buy this book. If you are a newbie just starting out with Magento or intermediate level Magento developer, I am sure you will find some valuable material here. Overall, in scale from 1 to 5, I would rate this book as 3.7/5. Topics and insights covered are a must know for every Magento developer. For more information about the [Magento 1.8 Development Cookbook] book see here.

item.title: Magento - "Your search returns no results" error, MySQL stopwords
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
Previously I wrote one article with the similar title here. This time its about another case where your search might return zero results. Figured I'll share my experience, possibly helping someone with the same issue. Recently I have been assigned a bug case on a Magento powered web shop. The bug report said "We are unable to search either on 'More' or 'More!' though you can paste the whole title in and it comes up OK.". At first I haven't related this issue to MySQL database as it worked locally on my machine. You gotta appreciate the "worked locally" cases when it comes to developers. Everything works, right! :) Anyhow, first step towards debugging the issue was to temporarily turn on the full MySQL query logging from Magento. You can do so by editing Varien_Db_Adapter_Pdo_Mysql class within /lib/Varien/Db/Adapter/Pdo/Mysql.php file turning on at least $_debug and $_logAllQueries as shown on the screen below. [caption id="attachment_488" align="alignnone" width="628"] Magento DB debug[/caption] After this was on, you can analyse the raw MySQL queries that go to database. In this case keep in mind that Magento System > Configuration > Catalog Catalog Search > Search Type [Like, Fulltext, Combine (Like and Fulltext)] will yield different sql queries, one of which looks like (searching for 'more' keyword in search) for Combine (Like and Fulltext) search type: 
INSERT INTO `catalogsearch_result` SELECT 7 AS `query_id`, `s`.`product_id`, MATCH (s.data_index) AGAINST (:query IN BOOLEAN MODE) AS `relevance` FROM `catalogsearch_fulltext` AS `s`
 INNER JOIN `catalog_product_entity` AS `e` ON e.entity_id = s.product_id WHERE (s.store_id = 1) AND (MATCH (s.data_index) AGAINST (:query IN BOOLEAN MODE) AND (`s`.`data_index` LIKE '%more%')) ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE `relevance` = VALUES(`relevance`)
BIND: array (
  ':query' => ' "more"',
)
Notice the BOOLEAN MODE in query. MySQL can perform boolean full-text searches using the IN BOOLEAN MODE modifier, as noted here. Also, for BOOLEAN MODE, the stopword list applies, controlled by innodb_ft_enable_stopword, innodb_ft_server_stopword_table, and innodb_ft_user_stopword_table for InnoDB search indexes, and ft_stopword_file for MyISAM ones. If you look at the sql CREATE code for the actual catalogsearch_fulltext table you can see it uses MyISAM engine as shown below. 
CREATE TABLE `catalogsearch_fulltext` (
	`fulltext_id` INT(10) UNSIGNED NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT COMMENT 'Entity ID',
	`product_id` INT(10) UNSIGNED NOT NULL COMMENT 'Product ID',
	`store_id` SMALLINT(5) UNSIGNED NOT NULL COMMENT 'Store ID',
	`data_index` LONGTEXT NULL COMMENT 'Data index',
	PRIMARY KEY (`fulltext_id`),
	UNIQUE INDEX `UNQ_CATALOGSEARCH_FULLTEXT_PRODUCT_ID_STORE_ID` (`product_id`, `store_id`),
	FULLTEXT INDEX `FTI_CATALOGSEARCH_FULLTEXT_DATA_INDEX` (`data_index`)
)
COMMENT='Catalog search result table'
COLLATE='utf8_general_ci'
ENGINE=MyISAM
AUTO_INCREMENT=1;
The ft_stopword_file defines the file from which to read the list of stopwords for full-text searches on MyISAM tables. The server looks for the file in the data directory unless an absolute path name is given to specify a different directory. All the words from the file are used; comments are not honored. By default, a built-in list of stopwords is used (as defined in the storage/myisam/ft_static.c file). Setting this variable to the empty string ('') disables stopword filtering. If you look at the actual list of Full-Text Stopwords, you can see that the "more" keyword is on the list. Luckily, the solution is simple and it comes down to these steps:
  • Edit my.ini / my.cnf file and add the following under to it ft_stopword_file = ""
  • Restart MySQL server
  • REPAIR TABLE catalogsearch_fulltext QUICK;
  • Reindex catalogsearch_fulltext in Magento
As you can see, FULLTEXT indexes on MyISAM tables must be rebuilt after changing this variable or the contents of the stopword file. We use the following sql query for that. 
REPAIR TABLE tbl_name QUICK;
After that we need to rebuilt the catalogsearch_fulltext in Magento either through console command as shown below. 
cd shell/
php indexer.php --reindex catalogsearch_fulltext
Or by going to Magento admin under System > Index Management > Catalog Search Index > Reindex Data. Now you should be able to get some search results in your Magento for what were previously marked as stopwords, if you have any of those strings in your searchable attributes. Hope this helps.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Magento, MySQL, search, stop, word, stopwords, stopword, more, query
Shows a solution for "Your search returns no results" error which in this case was caused by MySQL stopwords
Magento – "Your search returns no results" error, MySQL stopwords

item.title: Writing your first Drupal module
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
As of recently, Drupal became a second platform I am using / developing for in my day to day job. The first one still being the Magento. Why Drupal you might ask, given the wast amount of other PHP based platforms out there? The answer is simple, company I am working for at the moment has a long(ish) history of Drupal projects, so it made sense for me to tackle the challenge of this old-new platform. To be honest I had a huge prejudice about Drupal. Serves me right reading shallow comments from people who barely did a project or two in their life. Every platform has its strengths and weaknesses. Given my experience with Magento I could talk hours on this topic. Still, its up to developer to master these weeks and strengths and deliver the best to his knowledge. Similar to Magento v2, Drupal v8 is in active development, announcing great things to come:
  • Mobile in its DNA (mobile first)
  • Multilingual Capabilities (has them already, now enhanced)
  • Built-in Web Services (Hypertext Application Language)
  • Views, Out of the Box (popular Drupal add-on module now built into the core CMS)
  • Better Markup with HTML 5
  • Industry Standard Approach (more modern, object-oriented code)
Seems a bit of a right timing to jump start with this one, at least for me. In this first article on Drupal, I will give a quick introduction on building your first Drupal 7 module. Now, there are already dozen of articles and books on this topic, so mine might not be special in any regards. I simply like to write about stuff I do, from my own perspective and experiences. To be honest, compared to complexities of Magento, Drupal seems far more easier to jump start, so there is a little self pleasing note to this article as well :) Our module will be called "Hello" and namespaced under "Foggyline".

Module location

Contributed and custom modules in Drupal go under /sites/all/modules/ folder. Do not get mislead with the /modules/ folder found in the root of Drupal, this one is strictly for Drupal core system. Under the /sites/all/modules/ folder we need to create a sub-folder matching the name of our module. We do so by trying to incorporate the namespace + module name, like /sites/all/modules/foggyline_hello/.

The .info file

Once we have the folder in place, we need to create an .info file within it, sort of manifest or register file. This is the files that makes Drupal aware of your module. Name of the file must match the name of the module, which in our case is the name of the foggyline_hello folder, which gives final info file name like /sites/all/modules/foggyline_hello/foggyline_hello.info with the minimal following content. 
name = Foggyline Hello
description = "My first Drupal module."
package = Foggyline
core = 7.x
files[] = foggyline_hello.module
The above definition results in a module being visible under admin/modules menu like shown below. [caption id="attachment_570" align="alignnone" width="604"] Foggyline Hello - Drupal Module[/caption] Elements name, description, package are sort of self description in this way. The core element defines the version of Drupal this module is built for. The files element represents the array or list of files that Drupal should autoload. The way it works is that when a module is enabled, Drupal will rescan all declared files and index all the classes and interfaces that it finds. Classes will be loaded automatically by PHP when they are first accessed. There are other elements you can define within .info file. For more detailed information see this post.

The .module file

Now that Drupal became aware of our module through info file, its time to put some actual PHP code / logic in it. We do so through .module file. To make one thing perfectly clear, what Drupal calls .module file, it is just a .php file (PHP code) with .module extension. Depending on your IDE/editor you might want to adjust your syntax highlight to match PHP code. For our module purposes we need to create /sites/all/modules/foggyline_hello/foggyline_hello.module file. The PHP code we put into this file at the moment will sort of hang in the air. Reason for this is that Drupal is built on system of hooks, or in PHP jargon the callbacks. Those coming from object oriented PHP systems like Magento can look at this as sort of event/observer thing.

Implementing a hook

In order for our PHP code within foggyline_hello.module to make something useful, we need to implement some of the hooks available. You can find a list of hooks for Drupal 7 here. Lets pick one, lets say hook_node_view and implement it. So how exactly do we implement a hook? Easy, start by studying its function implementation, in this case we look for function called hook_node_view within Drupal. Documentation itself states the function can be found in /modules/node/node.api.php file. Even so, don't be afraid to actually open the file yourself and look for the function on your own. Following is the code behind the function. 
/**
 * Act on a node that is being assembled before rendering.
 *
 * The module may add elements to $node->content prior to rendering. This hook
 * will be called after hook_view(). The structure of $node->content is a
 * renderable array as expected by drupal_render().
 *
 * When $view_mode is 'rss', modules can also add extra RSS elements and
 * namespaces to $node->rss_elements and $node->rss_namespaces respectively for
 * the RSS item generated for this node.
 * For details on how this is used, see node_feed().
 *
 * @see blog_node_view()
 * @see forum_node_view()
 * @see comment_node_view()
 *
 * @param $node
 *   The node that is being assembled for rendering.
 * @param $view_mode
 *   The $view_mode parameter from node_view().
 * @param $langcode
 *   The language code used for rendering.
 *
 * @see hook_entity_view()
 *
 * @ingroup node_api_hooks
 */
function hook_node_view($node, $view_mode, $langcode) {
  $node->content['my_additional_field'] = array(
    '#markup' => $additional_field,
    '#weight' => 10,
    '#theme' => 'mymodule_my_additional_field',
  );
}
One thing I really like about Drupal is the documentation. Everything seems so nicely documented. Right, to repeat the question again, how do we "implement" the hook? Here comes the magic, you simply create the function called foggyline_hello_node_view within our foggyline_hello.module file. Logical next question would be; where did the foggyline_hello_node_view name came from? Easy, you take a full hook function name, then remove the "hook" part from it and replace it with your module name. This way hook_node_view becomes foggyline_hello_node_view. This is the first important thing to remember. The second important thing to remember is that your hook implementation function must contain/accept the same arguments as original hook. As a result our /sites/all/modules/foggyline_hello/foggyline_hello.module file now has the following content. 
function foggyline_hello_node_view($node, $view_mode, $langcode) {
    //Here goes our module code
}
At this point you might want to go back to admin/modules menu and enable your module. If you did so initially, then you might want to go under admin/config/development/performance menu and click on the "Clear all caches". If you now replace the "//Here goes our module code" string with PHP exit('Test...'); you should be able to see just "Test..." string in your browser when you visit the frontend area of your Drupal. Mission accomplished, we have implemented our first hook in Drupal. This one however does not do anything noteworthy; so lets try to make it a tiny bit more useful. If you do a dump of $node variable, you get something like following. 
stdClass Object
(
    [vid] => 3
    [uid] => 1
    [title] => Test me
    [log] => 
    [status] => 1
    [comment] => 2
    [promote] => 1
    [sticky] => 0
    [nid] => 3
    [type] => article
    [language] => hr
    [created] => 1399316006
    [changed] => 1399316006
    [tnid] => 0
    [translate] => 0
    [revision_timestamp] => 1399316006
    [revision_uid] => 1
    [body] => Array
        (
            [und] => Array
                (
                    [0] => Array
                        (
                            [value] => Test me nicely.
                            [summary] => 
                            [format] => filtered_html
                            [safe_value] => 
Test me nicely.



                            [safe_summary] => 
                        )

                )

        )
Conclusions? We are dealing with object of stdClass, and we know that objects in PHP are passed by reference. Knowing that we can easily change the node title, adding it a prefix "NEW: " like shown below. 
function foggyline_hello_node_view($node, $view_mode, $langcode) {
    if ((time() - $node->created) <= 3600) {
        $node->title = 'NEW: '.$node->title;
    }
}
Note: This will work on a homepage as shown below, but not directly on the node page as other hooks kick in there. [caption id="attachment_573" align="alignnone" width="896"] Drupal hook_node_view[/caption] From this point forward don't be afraid to experiment with var_dump, print_r or other debug functions dumping and changing hook/function arguments, etc. Pay special attention to what individual hook functions return originally, if they return anything, how their arguments are passed (value vs. reference), etc. Hope this helps.

Learn how to create your first Drupal 7.x module. Quick example implementing hook_node_view.

item.title: Extending Drupal with Hooks
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
In order to truly extend Drupal you need to understand the concepts behind hooks. Hooks are basically a PHP function callbacks that follow a certain naming pattern, those with background in OOP can think of hooks as event/observer thing. Lets get hands-on with this one.

The .info and .module file

We start by defining our module named "Hat" (short from "Hooks, Actions, Triggers") and namespaced under "Foggyline". This is done by defining the .info file /sites/all/modules/foggyline_hat/foggyline_hat.info as shown below. 
name = Foggyline HAT
description = "Example module for testing Hooks, Actions, Triggers."
package = Foggyline
core = 7.x
files[] = foggyline_hat.module
Once we have defined .info file, we need to define our actual PHP code containing file, the .module file /sites/all/modules/foggyline_hat/foggyline_hat.module. Once we have these two in place, login to your Drupal administration area and go under Modules. You should see Foggyline HAT on the list of available modules as shown in the photo below. [caption id="attachment_604" align="alignnone" width="604"] Foggyline HAT[/caption] For the moment we have merely "registered" our module with Drupal. The .module itself is an empty file for the moment so it does not do anything.

The Hooks

Drupal's module system is based on the concept of hooks. To extend Drupal, a module simply needs to implement a certain hook. List of hooks can be found on this page. This is not the final list of hooks you can hook into, as hooks can be defined your third party modules as well. In order to demonstrate the hook system, lets give ourselves a task of changing the "WHO'S ONLINE" label in the left footer area block. We will change the label to "CURRENTLY ONLINE". The most difficult part in this process is actually finding the right hook, which requires either previous experience or patience reading the Drupal documentation. Lets say our choice of hooks comes down to:
  • hook_block_view($delta = ''): Return a rendered or renderable view of a block.
  • hook_block_view_alter(&$data, $block): Perform alterations to the content of a block.
The hook_block_view hook is not really a viable option, something you'll figure out on your own if you try to implement it.

Implementing (existing) hook

In order to implement a hook we simply need to follow a certain naming pattern, which gives the final name of foggyline_hat_block_view_alter for our function. Notice how the final name is a result of our module name, plus the hook name we are implementing, minus the "hook" prefix. At this point, please be sure to visit admin/config/development/performance and click on the "Clear all caches" so that Drupal can register these hook implementations. If we put something like below into our foggyline_hat.module, 
function foggyline_hat_block_view_alter(&$data, $block) {
    echo '
'; print_r($data); echo '
';
    echo '
'; print_r($block); echo '
';
}
then once we clear the cache we would get something like following on frotnend for individual blocks. 
Array
(
    [subject] => Who's online
    [content] => 
There is currently 1 user online.
  • ajzele
    • 


)


stdClass Object
(
    [bid] => 21
    [module] => user
    [delta] => online
    [theme] => bartik
    [status] => 1
    [weight] => -8
    [region] => footer_firstcolumn
    [custom] => 0
    [visibility] => 0
    [pages] => 
    [title] => 
    [cache] => -1
)
The above variable dump is specific to the actual "WHO'S ONLINE" block. The Array type is from &$data variable and stdClass Object is from $block variable. Simply by observing variable content and structure you can conclude that changing the "WHO'S ONLINE" to "CURRENTLY ONLINE" is simply a matter of modifying the referenced $data variable, as shown below. 
function foggyline_hat_block_view_alter(&$data, $block) {
    if ($block->module == 'user' && $block->delta == 'online') {
        $data['subject'] = 'Currently online';
    }
}
Example above simply "targets" the specific block by using module and delta of a $block object, to avoid modifying other modules blocks. The whole magic here is actually very simple; hooks pass the variables by reference and you simply modify those variables and/or add extra code in your hook implementation do so something extra besides just modifying the passed variables. Combine this simple approach with a large number of hooks you can hook into, and you get a extendible system.

Declaring your own hook

Sometimes however, you might want to define your own hooks. Drupal provides several of its own hooks that enable you do all sort of things along that path.
  • module_hook: Determines whether a module implements a hook.
  • module_hook_info: Retrieves a list of hooks that are declared through hook_hook_info().
  • module_implements: Determines which modules are implementing a hook.
  • module_implements_write_cache: Writes the hook implementation cache.
  • module_invoke: Invokes a hook in a particular module.
  • module_invoke_all: Invokes a hook in all enabled modules that implement it.
One thing to note here, "defining" our custom hook in this context simply means calling for execution of all function implementations that hook into this hook (if any). We are not actually entitled to define some logical code for our hook, or hook itself, the only thing we need to define is this case is a call to imaginary "hook_foggylicious_stuff" hook, implying the hook name "foggylicious_stuff" like shown below. 
/**
 * Implementation of hook_block_view_alter().
 */
function foggyline_hat_block_view_alter(&$data, $block) {
    if ($block->module == 'user' && $block->delta == 'online') {
        foggyline_hat_trigger_my_custom_hook();        
    }
}

/**
 * Just some custom function triggering foggylicious_stuff hooks.
 */
function foggyline_hat_trigger_my_custom_hook() {
    /** Invokes a "{hook_}foggylicious_stuff" hook in all enabled modules that implement it. */
    module_invoke_all('foggylicious_stuff');
}

/**
 * Implementation of hook_foggylicious_stuff().
 */
function foggyline_hat_foggylicious_stuff() {
    var_dump('foggylicious_stuff...');
}
Note the line where it says module_invoke_all('foggylicious_stuff');, what this single line of code means to system is following: "hey, I just dispatched a call for all {xyz_module}_foggylicious_stuff()" functions. Code example below seems a bit more complex then it should be, because it is. What we are doing in the above example is triggering "foggylicious_stuff" hook within the "hook_block_view_alter" implementation. This is just so we build upon previous example. Also, our own module then implements the "foggylicious_stuff" hook by defining foggyline_hat_foggylicious_stuff()function, which is basically unnecessary. Again, this is just for the demo purposes. Your module does not actually need to define the implementation of a hook. It can merely implement the call/invocation of a hook. Other modules are here do define the implementation if they want to extend your code. Its up to you as a module developer/designer to place your custom hook invocations on a proper "path"/places in your code. [caption id="attachment_601" align="alignnone" width="604"] Drupal hooks output debug[/caption] If we quickly duplicate our foggyline_hat module into foggyline_hat2, and replace the content of foggyline_hat2.module with just the following 
/**
 * Implementation of hook_foggylicious_stuff().
 */
function foggyline_hat2_foggylicious_stuff() {
    var_dump('foggyline_hat2_foggylicious_stuff...');
}
you can see in the screen below that this too gets triggered nicely, meaning our "custom hook" definition from foggyline_hat module works. [caption id="attachment_600" align="alignnone" width="604"] Drupal hooks output debug[/caption] Hope this helps.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Quick introduction to Drupal hooks. Shows how to implement existing hook and declare custom hook.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: What's the proper naming conventions for defining hooks? If a hook is specific to the function that calls it, doesn't it make sense to name it after that function? ie, function my_module_save_node() { module_invoke_all( 'my_module_save_node' ); }

item.title: Get a Magento v2.x book by donating to Croatian Red Cross
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded: As some of you following (international) news might know, thousands of people are left homeless, without food, water, and warm and dry clothes due to severe flooding in Croatia, Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. I can't even imagine a horror of loosing your home, some of which are lost permanently. It is moment like these that show our true humanity. This way I'd like to appeal to my Magento developer friends out there to help out with a little $10 donation. Everyone who does so, will get a free copy of my two (future) micro-books on Magento v2.x (Magento Payment Methods, Magento Shipping Methods). Just email me a payment slip/receipt to ajzele AT gmail.com when you do so. They need your help! Click HERE to donate to the Red Cross organisations which are leading the humanitarian efforts in the region. Huge thanks to anyone able to help.

item.title: Performance efficient and lightweight Magento-Elasticsearch integration, part 1
item.dc:creator: branko
item.content:encoded:
This is the first out of (possibly) series of articles on Magento and Elasticsearch integration, as I develop my Foggyline_Elastic extension. Given the busy nature of my full time job, its gonna take some time for follow ups, though they are coming. In this article I will give you a rough overview of how you can make performance efficient and lightweight Magento and Elasticsearch integration. Given the upcoming Magento version 2 on the way, I want to make it clear, thoughts presented here apply on Magento version 1.x, more specifically v1.9. However, I am sure that the same principles could be applied to the upcoming version 2, just not to the copy-paste letter of the word. That being said, lets outline a general scope of things, the high level specification if you like. The way Elasticsearch will be implemented is in completely unobtrusive manner, meaning we will not hack or override or in any other way replace the inner workings of default Magento quick search, advanced search or layered navigation. Additionally, we will implement it as a fully separate extension, that could be turned of at any point in time, leaving no side effects. The lightweight part of the extension applies to that fact that we will only focus on direct product entity data searching. Meaning we will ignore product categories, tags, potential reviews, CMS pages, etc. There are two major areas of work here:
  • aggregation and synchronization of Magento product data that will be sent to Elasticsearch for indexing and updating
  • Magento front-end implementation, things like taking ownership of Magento quick search input field and search results page
Aggregation part will be implemented in utmost simplified manner. We will not be writing our own indexers or such. We will merely hook into Magento catalogsearch_fulltext index process, pull the data out of it and push it to Elasticsearch. Thus, the data pushed to Elasticsearch, will be pushed in same chunks as it is indexed in Magento. The catalogsearch_fulltext index process is reasonably fast when it comes to larger number of products, for example it takes roughly 30min for 300K products to index (on average SSD, Core i5, 8GB RAM, etc... completely non-scientific measures, but you get a feeling of it). Each time catalogsearch_fulltext is run, the appropriate Elasticsearch collection will be truncated, and refilled. Synchronization part will be implement in a standard Magento event/observer manner, targeting something like catalog_product_save_after event. Thus pushing individual product updates to Elasticsearch when needed. Once we sort out the back-end stuff (aggregation and synchronization) we can turn our focus to front-end implementation. By default Magento has two search facilities, one named Quick Search and other named Advanced Search. The "Quick Search" is basically form (HTML element with id="search_mini_form" and action="/catalogsearch/result/") with single input field (HTML element with id="search" and name="q"). The "Advanced Search" form is what you get when you visit /catalogsearch/advanced/ page. General idea here is to completely ignore the existence of /catalogsearch/advanced/ page and focus on Quick Search only. We use a touch of JavaScript to change the action value of "search_mini_form" element, pointing the submission to our custom controller action, lets say /elastic/search/. Within our Foggyline_Elastic_SearchController, class we define indexAction() method that will pick up the search submission, push it to Elasticsearch, and then render results into separate custom page (not Magento's Quick Search /catalogsearch/result/ and not Advanced Search /advanced/result/ page). We define special controller action (/elastic/search/result/), layout handles (.xml) and template files (.phmtl) for rendering this page. The biggest trick here is to somehow implement Magento style of listing products, like the one found under /app/design/frontend/base/default/template/catalog/product/list.phtml file. This way we get the same listing that Magento uses, so we automatically reuse theme styling, pager, sorter, and all other outputs that are result of special prices, catalogue rules, different product types, etc. In order to do that, high level approach is to grab the paged results returned from Elasticsearch, and then based on visible per page subset of products we reload them through Magento product collection and pass on to template file. To quickly get back to the starting statements, where I said "...we will not hack or override or in any other way replace default Magento quick search, advanced search...". Obviously, when Foggyline_Elastic gets turned on, a small JavaScript will be injected into page to change the action attribute value to use our extension controller action for submission. Once Foggyline_Elastic is disabled, the control returns back to Magento, so we are not permanently killing Magento's quick search features. As for "Advanced Search", it remains fully active, so its up to you to hide the links towards it, or to put some sort of redirect in your .htaccess file or in some other way disable it. Part two, coming soon...
